O LD  S ONG           When the Jester, arrayed in the cowl and frock of the hermit, and having his  knotted cord twisted round his middle, stood before the portal of the castle of  Front-de-Bœuf, the warder demanded of him his name and errand.          &ldquo;Pax vobiscum,&rdquo; answered the Jester, &ldquo;I am a poor brother of  the Order of St Francis, who come hither to do my office to certain unhappy  prisoners now secured within this castle.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou art a bold friar,&rdquo; said the warder, &ldquo;to come hither,  where, saving our own drunken confessor, a cock of thy feather hath not crowed  these twenty years.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Yet I pray thee, do mine errand to the lord of the castle,&rdquo;  answered the pretended friar; &ldquo;trust me it will find good acceptance with  him, and the cock shall crow, that the whole castle shall hear him.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Gramercy,&rdquo; said the warder; &ldquo;but if I come to shame for  leaving my post upon thine errand, I will try whether a friar&rsquo;s grey gown  be proof against a grey-goose shaft.&rdquo;          With this threat he left his turret, and carried to the hall of the castle his  unwonted intelligence, that a holy friar stood before the gate and demanded  instant admission. With no small wonder he received his master&rsquo;s commands  to admit the holy man immediately; and, having previously manned the entrance  to guard against surprise, he obeyed, without further scruple, the commands  which he had received. The harebrained self-conceit which had emboldened Wamba  to undertake this dangerous office, was scarce sufficient to support him when  he found himself in the presence of a man so dreadful, and so much dreaded, as  Reginald Front-de-Bœuf, and he brought out his &ldquo;pax vobiscum&rdquo;, to  which he, in a good measure, trusted for supporting his character, with more  anxiety and hesitation than had hitherto accompanied it. But Front-de-Bœuf was  accustomed to see men of all ranks tremble in his presence, so that the  timidity of the supposed father did not give him any cause of suspicion.          &ldquo;Who and whence art thou, priest?&rdquo; said he.          &ldquo;&lsquo;Pax vobiscum&rsquo;,&rdquo; reiterated the Jester, &ldquo;I am a  poor servant of St Francis, who, travelling through this wilderness, have  fallen among thieves, (as Scripture hath it,) &lsquo;quidam viator incidit in  latrones&rsquo;, which thieves have sent me unto this castle in order to do my  ghostly office on two persons condemned by your honourable justice.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay, right,&rdquo; answered Front-de-Bœuf; &ldquo;and canst thou tell  me, holy father, the number of those banditti?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Gallant sir,&rdquo; answered the Jester, &ldquo;&lsquo;nomen illis  legio&rsquo;, their name is legion.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Tell me in plain terms what numbers there are, or, priest, thy cloak and  cord will ill protect thee.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Alas!&rdquo; said the supposed friar, &ldquo;&lsquo;cor meum  eructavit&rsquo;, that is to say, I was like to burst with fear! but I conceive  they may be&mdash;what of yeomen&mdash;what of commons, at least five hundred  men.&rdquo;          &ldquo;What!&rdquo; said the Templar, who came into the hall that moment,  &ldquo;muster the wasps so thick here? it is time to stifle such a mischievous  brood.&rdquo; Then taking Front-de-Bœuf aside &ldquo;Knowest thou the  priest?&rdquo;          &ldquo;He is a stranger from a distant convent,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf;  &ldquo;I know him not.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Then trust him not with thy purpose in words,&rdquo; answered the  Templar. &ldquo;Let him carry a written order to De Bracy&rsquo;s company of  Free Companions, to repair instantly to their master&rsquo;s aid. In the  meantime, and that the shaveling may suspect nothing, permit him to go freely  about his task of preparing these Saxon hogs for the slaughter-house.&rdquo;          &ldquo;It shall be so,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf. And he forthwith appointed a  domestic to conduct Wamba to the apartment where Cedric and Athelstane were  confined.          The impatience of Cedric had been rather enhanced than diminished by his  confinement. He walked from one end of the hall to the other, with the attitude  of one who advances to charge an enemy, or to storm the breach of a beleaguered  place, sometimes ejaculating to himself, sometimes addressing Athelstane, who  stoutly and stoically awaited the issue of the adventure, digesting, in the  meantime, with great composure, the liberal meal which he had made at noon, and  not greatly interesting himself about the duration of his captivity, which he  concluded, would, like all earthly evils, find an end in Heaven&rsquo;s good  time.          &ldquo;&lsquo;Pax vobiscum&rsquo;,&rdquo; said the Jester, entering the  apartment; &ldquo;the blessing of St Dunstan, St Dennis, St Duthoc, and all  other saints whatsoever, be upon ye and about ye.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Enter freely,&rdquo; answered Cedric to the supposed friar; &ldquo;with  what intent art thou come hither?&rdquo;          &ldquo;To bid you prepare yourselves for death,&rdquo; answered the Jester.          &ldquo;It is impossible!&rdquo; replied Cedric, starting. &ldquo;Fearless and  wicked as they are, they dare not attempt such open and gratuitous  cruelty!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Alas!&rdquo; said the Jester, &ldquo;to restrain them by their sense of  humanity, is the same as to stop a runaway horse with a bridle of silk thread.  Bethink thee, therefore, noble Cedric, and you also, gallant Athelstane, what  crimes you have committed in the flesh; for this very day will ye be called to  answer at a higher tribunal.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Hearest thou this, Athelstane?&rdquo; said Cedric; &ldquo;we must rouse  up our hearts to this last action, since better it is we should die like men,  than live like slaves.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am ready,&rdquo; answered Athelstane, &ldquo;to stand the worst of  their malice, and shall walk to my death with as much composure as ever I did  to my dinner.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Let us then unto our holy gear, father,&rdquo; said Cedric.          &ldquo;Wait yet a moment, good uncle,&rdquo; said the Jester, in his natural  tone; &ldquo;better look long before you leap in the dark.&rdquo;          &ldquo;By my faith,&rdquo; said Cedric, &ldquo;I should know that voice!&rdquo;          &ldquo;It is that of your trusty slave and jester,&rdquo; answered Wamba,  throwing back his cowl. &ldquo;Had you taken a fool&rsquo;s advice formerly,  you would not have been here at all. Take a fool&rsquo;s advice now, and you  will not be here long.&rdquo;          &ldquo;How mean&rsquo;st thou, knave?&rdquo; answered the Saxon.          &ldquo;Even thus,&rdquo; replied Wamba; &ldquo;take thou this frock and cord,  which are all the orders I ever had, and march quietly out of the castle,  leaving me your cloak and girdle to take the long leap in thy stead.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Leave thee in my stead!&rdquo; said Cedric, astonished at the proposal;  &ldquo;why, they would hang thee, my poor knave.&rdquo;          &ldquo;E&rsquo;en let them do as they are permitted,&rdquo; said Wamba;  &ldquo;I trust&mdash;no disparagement to your birth&mdash;that the son of  Witless may hang in a chain with as much gravity as the chain hung upon his  ancestor the alderman.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Well, Wamba,&rdquo; answered Cedric, &ldquo;for one thing will I grant  thy request. And that is, if thou wilt make the exchange of garments with Lord  Athelstane instead of me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;No, by St Dunstan,&rdquo; answered Wamba; &ldquo;there were little  reason in that. Good right there is, that the son of Witless should suffer to  save the son of Hereward; but little wisdom there were in his dying for the  benefit of one whose fathers were strangers to his.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Villain,&rdquo; said Cedric, &ldquo;the fathers of Athelstane were  monarchs of England!&rdquo;          &ldquo;They might be whomsoever they pleased,&rdquo; replied Wamba; &ldquo;but  my neck stands too straight upon my shoulders to have it twisted for their  sake. Wherefore, good my master, either take my proffer yourself, or suffer me  to leave this dungeon as free as I entered.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Let the old tree wither,&rdquo; continued Cedric, &ldquo;so the stately  hope of the forest be preserved. Save the noble Athelstane, my trusty Wamba! it  is the duty of each who has Saxon blood in his veins. Thou and I will abide  together the utmost rage of our injurious oppressors, while he, free and safe,  shall arouse the awakened spirits of our countrymen to avenge us.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Not so, father Cedric,&rdquo; said Athelstane, grasping his  hand,&mdash;for, when roused to think or act, his deeds and sentiments were not  unbecoming his high race&mdash;&ldquo;Not so,&rdquo; he continued; &ldquo;I  would rather remain in this hall a week without food save the prisoner&rsquo;s  stinted loaf, or drink save the prisoner&rsquo;s measure of water, than embrace  the opportunity to escape which the slave&rsquo;s untaught kindness has  purveyed for his master.&rdquo;          &ldquo;You are called wise men, sirs,&rdquo; said the Jester, &ldquo;and I a  crazed fool; but, uncle Cedric, and cousin Athelstane, the fool shall decide  this controversy for ye, and save ye the trouble of straining courtesies any  farther. I am like John-a-Duck&rsquo;s mare, that will let no man mount her but  John-a-Duck. I came to save my master, and if he will not  consent&mdash;basta&mdash;I can but go away home again. Kind service cannot be  chucked from hand to hand like a shuttlecock or stool-ball. I&rsquo;ll hang for  no man but my own born master.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Go, then, noble Cedric,&rdquo; said Athelstane, &ldquo;neglect not this  opportunity. Your presence without may encourage friends to our  rescue&mdash;your remaining here would ruin us all.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And is there any prospect, then, of rescue from without?&rdquo; said  Cedric, looking to the Jester.          &ldquo;Prospect, indeed!&rdquo; echoed Wamba; &ldquo;let me tell you, when you  fill my cloak, you are wrapped in a general&rsquo;s cassock. Five hundred men  are there without, and I was this morning one of the chief leaders. My  fool&rsquo;s cap was a casque, and my bauble a truncheon. Well, we shall see  what good they will make by exchanging a fool for a wise man. Truly, I fear  they will lose in valour what they may gain in discretion. And so farewell,  master, and be kind to poor Gurth and his dog Fangs; and let my cockscomb hang  in the hall at Rotherwood, in memory that I flung away my life for my master,  like a faithful&mdash;-fool.&rdquo;          The last word came out with a sort of double expression, betwixt jest and  earnest. The tears stood in Cedric&rsquo;s eyes.          &ldquo;Thy memory shall be preserved,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;while fidelity and  affection have honour upon earth! But that I trust I shall find the means of  saving Rowena, and thee, Athelstane, and thee, also, my poor Wamba, thou  shouldst not overbear me in this matter.&rdquo;          The exchange of dress was now accomplished, when a sudden doubt struck Cedric.          &ldquo;I know no language,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;but my own, and a few words  of their mincing Norman. How shall I bear myself like a reverend  brother?&rdquo;          &ldquo;The spell lies in two words,&rdquo; replied  Wamba&mdash;&ldquo;&lsquo;Pax vobiscum&rsquo; will answer all queries. If you  go or come, eat or drink, bless or ban, &lsquo;Pax vobiscum&rsquo; carries you  through it all. It is as useful to a friar as a broomstick to a witch, or a  wand to a conjurer. Speak it but thus, in a deep grave tone,&mdash;&lsquo;Pax  vobiscum!&rsquo;&mdash;it is irresistible&mdash;Watch and ward, knight and  squire, foot and horse, it acts as a charm upon them all. I think, if they  bring me out to be hanged to-morrow, as is much to be doubted they may, I will  try its weight upon the finisher of the sentence.&rdquo;          &ldquo;If such prove the case,&rdquo; said the master, &ldquo;my religious  orders are soon taken&mdash;&lsquo;Pax vobiscum&rsquo;. I trust I shall  remember the pass-word.&mdash;Noble Athelstane, farewell; and farewell, my poor  boy, whose heart might make amends for a weaker head&mdash;I will save you, or  return and die with you. The royal blood of our Saxon kings shall not be spilt  while mine beats in my veins; nor shall one hair fall from the head of the kind  knave who risked himself for his master, if Cedric&rsquo;s peril can prevent  it.&mdash;Farewell.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Farewell, noble Cedric,&rdquo; said Athelstane; &ldquo;remember it is  the true part of a friar to accept refreshment, if you are offered any.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Farewell, uncle,&rdquo; added Wamba; &ldquo;and remember &lsquo;Pax  vobiscum&rsquo;.&rdquo;          Thus exhorted, Cedric sallied forth upon his expedition; and it was not long  ere he had occasion to try the force of that spell which his Jester had  recommended as omnipotent. In a low-arched and dusky passage, by which he  endeavoured to work his way to the hall of the castle, he was interrupted by a  female form.          &ldquo;&lsquo;Pax vobiscum!&rsquo;&rdquo; said the pseudo friar, and was  endeavouring to hurry past, when a soft voice replied, &ldquo;&lsquo;Et  vobis&mdash;quaso, domine reverendissime, pro misericordia  vestra&rsquo;.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am somewhat deaf,&rdquo; replied Cedric, in good Saxon, and at the  same time muttered to himself, &ldquo;A curse on the fool and his &lsquo;Pax  vobiscum!&rsquo; I have lost my javelin at the first cast.&rdquo;          It was, however, no unusual thing for a priest of those days to be deaf of his  Latin ear, and this the person who now addressed Cedric knew full well.          &ldquo;I pray you of dear love, reverend father,&rdquo; she replied in his own  language, &ldquo;that you will deign to visit with your ghostly comfort a  wounded prisoner of this castle, and have such compassion upon him and us as  thy holy office teaches&mdash;Never shall good deed so highly advantage thy  convent.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Daughter,&rdquo; answered Cedric, much embarrassed, &ldquo;my time in  this castle will not permit me to exercise the duties of mine office&mdash;I  must presently forth&mdash;there is life and death upon my speed.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Yet, father, let me entreat you by the vow you have taken on you,&rdquo;  replied the suppliant, &ldquo;not to leave the oppressed and endangered without  counsel or succour.&rdquo;          &ldquo;May the fiend fly away with me, and leave me in Ifrin with the souls of  Odin and of Thor!&rdquo; answered Cedric impatiently, and would probably have  proceeded in the same tone of total departure from his spiritual character,  when the colloquy was interrupted by the harsh voice of Urfried, the old crone  of the turret.          &ldquo;How, minion,&rdquo; said she to the female speaker, &ldquo;is this the  manner in which you requite the kindness which permitted thee to leave thy  prison-cell yonder?&mdash;Puttest thou the reverend man to use ungracious  language to free himself from the importunities of a Jewess?&rdquo;          &ldquo;A Jewess!&rdquo; said Cedric, availing himself of the information to get  clear of their interruption,&mdash;&ldquo;Let me pass, woman! stop me not at  your peril. I am fresh from my holy office, and would avoid pollution.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Come this way, father,&rdquo; said the old hag, &ldquo;thou art a  stranger in this castle, and canst not leave it without a guide. Come hither,  for I would speak with thee.&mdash;And you, daughter of an accursed race, go to  the sick man&rsquo;s chamber, and tend him until my return; and woe betide you  if you again quit it without my permission!&rdquo;          Rebecca retreated. Her importunities had prevailed upon Urfried to suffer her  to quit the turret, and Urfried had employed her services where she herself  would most gladly have paid them, by the bedside of the wounded Ivanhoe. With  an understanding awake to their dangerous situation, and prompt to avail  herself of each means of safety which occurred, Rebecca had hoped something  from the presence of a man of religion, who, she learned from Urfried, had  penetrated into this godless castle. She watched the return of the supposed  ecclesiastic, with the purpose of addressing him, and interesting him in favour  of the prisoners; with what imperfect success the reader has been just  acquainted.                     CHAPTER XXVII        Fond wretch! and what canst thou relate,   But deeds of sorrow, shame, and sin?   Thy deeds are proved&mdash;thou know&rsquo;st thy fate;   But come, thy tale&mdash;begin&mdash;begin.               But I have griefs of other kind,   Troubles and sorrows more severe;   Give me to ease my tortured mind,   Lend to my woes a patient ear;   And let me, if I may not find   A friend to help&mdash;find one to hear.          C RABBE&rsquo;S  H ALL OF  J USTICE           When Urfried had with clamours and menaces driven Rebecca back to the apartment  from which she had sallied, she proceeded to conduct the unwilling Cedric into  a small apartment, the door of which she heedfully secured. Then fetching from  a cupboard a stoup of wine and two flagons, she placed them on the table, and  said in a tone rather asserting a fact than asking a question, &ldquo;Thou art  Saxon, father&mdash;Deny it not,&rdquo; she continued, observing that Cedric  hastened not to reply; &ldquo;the sounds of my native language are sweet to  mine ears, though seldom heard save from the tongues of the wretched and  degraded serfs on whom the proud Normans impose the meanest drudgery of this  dwelling. Thou art a Saxon, father&mdash;a Saxon, and, save as thou art a  servant of God, a freeman.&mdash;Thine accents are sweet in mine ear.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Do not Saxon priests visit this castle, then?&rdquo; replied Cedric;  &ldquo;it were, methinks, their duty to comfort the outcast and oppressed  children of the soil.&rdquo;          &ldquo;They come not&mdash;or if they come, they better love to revel at the  boards of their conquerors,&rdquo; answered Urfried, &ldquo;than to hear the  groans of their countrymen&mdash;so, at least, report speaks of them&mdash;of  myself I can say little. This castle, for ten years, has opened to no priest  save the debauched Norman chaplain who partook the nightly revels of  Front-de-Bœuf, and he has been long gone to render an account of his  stewardship.&mdash;But thou art a Saxon&mdash;a Saxon priest, and I have one  question to ask of thee.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am a Saxon,&rdquo; answered Cedric, &ldquo;but unworthy, surely, of  the name of priest. Let me begone on my way&mdash;I swear I will return, or  send one of our fathers more worthy to hear your confession.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Stay yet a while,&rdquo; said Urfried; &ldquo;the accents of the voice  which thou hearest now will soon be choked with the cold earth, and I would not  descend to it like the beast I have lived. But wine must give me strength to  tell the horrors of my tale.&rdquo; She poured out a cup, and drank it with a  frightful avidity, which seemed desirous of draining the last drop in the  goblet. &ldquo;It stupifies,&rdquo; she said, looking upwards as she finished  her drought, &ldquo;but it cannot cheer&mdash;Partake it, father, if you would  hear my tale without sinking down upon the pavement.&rdquo; Cedric would have  avoided pledging her in this ominous conviviality, but the sign which she made  to him expressed impatience and despair. He complied with her request, and  answered her challenge in a large wine-cup; she then proceeded with her story,  as if appeased by his complaisance.          &ldquo;I was not born,&rdquo; she said, &ldquo;father, the wretch that thou now  seest me. I was free, was happy, was honoured, loved, and was beloved. I am now  a slave, miserable and degraded&mdash;the sport of my masters&rsquo; passions  while I had yet beauty&mdash;the object of their contempt, scorn, and hatred,  since it has passed away. Dost thou wonder, father, that I should hate mankind,  and, above all, the race that has wrought this change in me? Can the wrinkled  decrepit hag before thee, whose wrath must vent itself in impotent curses,  forget she was once the daughter of the noble Thane of Torquilstone, before  whose frown a thousand vassals trembled?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou the daughter of Torquil Wolfganger!&rdquo; said Cedric, receding as  he spoke; &ldquo;thou&mdash;thou&mdash;the daughter of that noble Saxon, my  father&rsquo;s friend and companion in arms!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thy father&rsquo;s friend!&rdquo; echoed Urfried; &ldquo;then Cedric  called the Saxon stands before me, for the noble Hereward of Rotherwood had but  one son, whose name is well known among his countrymen. But if thou art Cedric  of Rotherwood, why this religious dress?&mdash;hast thou too despaired of  saving thy country, and sought refuge from oppression in the shade of the  convent?&rdquo;          &ldquo;It matters not who I am,&rdquo; said Cedric; &ldquo;proceed, unhappy  woman, with thy tale of horror and guilt!&mdash;Guilt there must be&mdash;there  is guilt even in thy living to tell it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;There is&mdash;there is,&rdquo; answered the wretched woman,  &ldquo;deep, black, damning guilt,&mdash;guilt, that lies like a load at my  breast&mdash;guilt, that all the penitential fires of hereafter cannot  cleanse.&mdash;Yes, in these halls, stained with the noble and pure blood of my  father and my brethren&mdash;in these very halls, to have lived the paramour of  their murderer, the slave at once and the partaker of his pleasures, was to  render every breath which I drew of vital air, a crime and a curse.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Wretched woman!&rdquo; exclaimed Cedric. &ldquo;And while the friends of  thy father&mdash;while each true Saxon heart, as it breathed a requiem for his  soul, and those of his valiant sons, forgot not in their prayers the murdered  Ulrica&mdash;while all mourned and honoured the dead, thou hast lived to merit  our hate and execration&mdash;lived to unite thyself with the vile tyrant who  murdered thy nearest and dearest&mdash;who shed the blood of infancy, rather  than a male of the noble house of Torquil Wolfganger should survive&mdash;with  him hast thou lived to unite thyself, and in the hands of lawless love!&rdquo;          &ldquo;In lawless hands, indeed, but not in those of love!&rdquo; answered the  hag; &ldquo;love will sooner visit the regions of eternal doom, than those  unhallowed vaults.&mdash;No, with that at least I cannot reproach  myself&mdash;hatred to Front-de-Bœuf and his race governed my soul most  deeply, even in the hour of his guilty endearments.&rdquo;          &ldquo;You hated him, and yet you lived,&rdquo; replied Cedric; &ldquo;wretch!  was there no poniard&mdash;no knife&mdash;no bodkin!&mdash;Well was it for  thee, since thou didst prize such an existence, that the secrets of a Norman  castle are like those of the grave. For had I but dreamed of the daughter of  Torquil living in foul communion with the murderer of her father, the sword of  a true Saxon had found thee out even in the arms of thy paramour!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Wouldst thou indeed have done this justice to the name of  Torquil?&rdquo; said Ulrica, for we may now lay aside her assumed name of  Urfried; &ldquo;thou art then the true Saxon report speaks thee! for even  within these accursed walls, where, as thou well sayest, guilt shrouds itself  in inscrutable mystery, even there has the name of Cedric been  sounded&mdash;and I, wretched and degraded, have rejoiced to think that there  yet breathed an avenger of our unhappy nation.&mdash;I also have had my hours  of vengeance&mdash;I have fomented the quarrels of our foes, and heated drunken  revelry into murderous broil&mdash;I have seen their blood flow&mdash;I have  heard their dying groans!&mdash;Look on me, Cedric&mdash;are there not still  left on this foul and faded face some traces of the features of Torquil?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ask me not of them, Ulrica,&rdquo; replied Cedric, in a tone of grief  mixed with abhorrence; &ldquo;these traces form such a resemblance as arises  from the graves of the dead, when a fiend has animated the lifeless  corpse.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Be it so,&rdquo; answered Ulrica; &ldquo;yet wore these fiendish  features the mask of a spirit of light when they were able to set at variance  the elder Front-de-Bœuf and his son Reginald! The darkness of hell should hide  what followed, but revenge must lift the veil, and darkly intimate what it  would raise the dead to speak aloud. Long had the smouldering fire of discord  glowed between the tyrant father and his savage son&mdash;long had I nursed, in  secret, the unnatural hatred&mdash;it blazed forth in an hour of drunken  wassail, and at his own board fell my oppressor by the hand of his own  son&mdash;such are the secrets these vaults conceal!&mdash;Rend asunder, ye  accursed arches,&rdquo; she added, looking up towards the roof, &ldquo;and bury  in your fall all who are conscious of the hideous mystery!&rdquo;          &ldquo;And thou, creature of guilt and misery,&rdquo; said Cedric, &ldquo;what  became thy lot on the death of thy ravisher?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Guess it, but ask it not.&mdash;Here&mdash;here I dwelt, till age,  premature age, has stamped its ghastly features on my countenance&mdash;scorned  and insulted where I was once obeyed, and compelled to bound the revenge which  had once such ample scope, to the efforts of petty malice of a discontented  menial, or the vain or unheeded curses of an impotent hag&mdash;condemned to  hear from my lonely turret the sounds of revelry in which I once partook, or  the shrieks and groans of new victims of oppression.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ulrica,&rdquo; said Cedric, &ldquo;with a heart which still, I fear,  regrets the lost reward of thy crimes, as much as the deeds by which thou didst  acquire that meed, how didst thou dare to address thee to one who wears this  robe? Consider, unhappy woman, what could the sainted Edward himself do for  thee, were he here in bodily presence? The royal Confessor was endowed by  heaven with power to cleanse the ulcers of the body, but only God himself can  cure the leprosy of the soul.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Yet, turn not from me, stern prophet of wrath,&rdquo; she exclaimed,  &ldquo;but tell me, if thou canst, in what shall terminate these new and awful  feelings that burst on my solitude&mdash;Why do deeds, long since done, rise  before me in new and irresistible horrors? What fate is prepared beyond the  grave for her, to whom God has assigned on earth a lot of such unspeakable  wretchedness? Better had I turn to Woden, Hertha, and Zernebock&mdash;to Mista,  and to Skogula, the gods of our yet unbaptized ancestors, than endure the  dreadful anticipations which have of late haunted my waking and my sleeping  hours!&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am no priest,&rdquo; said Cedric, turning with disgust from this  miserable picture of guilt, wretchedness, and despair; &ldquo;I am no priest,  though I wear a priest&rsquo;s garment.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Priest or layman,&rdquo; answered Ulrica, &ldquo;thou art the first I  have seen for twenty years, by whom God was feared or man regarded; and dost  thou bid me despair?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I bid thee repent,&rdquo; said Cedric. &ldquo;Seek to prayer and  penance, and mayest thou find acceptance! But I cannot, I will not, longer  abide with thee.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Stay yet a moment!&rdquo; said Ulrica; &ldquo;leave me not now, son of  my father&rsquo;s friend, lest the demon who has governed my life should tempt  me to avenge myself of thy hard-hearted scorn&mdash;Thinkest thou, if  Front-de-Bœuf found Cedric the Saxon in his castle, in such a disguise, that  thy life would be a long one?&mdash;Already his eye has been upon thee like a  falcon on his prey.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And be it so,&rdquo; said Cedric; &ldquo;and let him tear me with beak  and talons, ere my tongue say one word which my heart doth not warrant. I will  die a Saxon&mdash;true in word, open in deed&mdash;I bid thee  avaunt!&mdash;touch me not, stay me not!&mdash;The sight of Front-de-Bœuf  himself is less odious to me than thou, degraded and degenerate as thou  art.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Be it so,&rdquo; said Ulrica, no longer interrupting him; &ldquo;go thy  way, and forget, in the insolence of thy superority, that the wretch before  thee is the daughter of thy father&rsquo;s friend.&mdash;Go thy way&mdash;if I  am separated from mankind by my sufferings&mdash;separated from those whose aid  I might most justly expect&mdash;not less will I be separated from them in my  revenge!&mdash;No man shall aid me, but the ears of all men shall tingle to  hear of the deed which I shall dare to do!&mdash;Farewell!&mdash;thy scorn has  burst the last tie which seemed yet to unite me to my kind&mdash;a thought that  my woes might claim the compassion of my people.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ulrica,&rdquo; said Cedric, softened by this appeal, &ldquo;hast thou  borne up and endured to live through so much guilt and so much misery, and wilt  thou now yield to despair when thine eyes are opened to thy crimes, and when  repentance were thy fitter occupation?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Cedric,&rdquo; answered Ulrica, &ldquo;thou little knowest the human  heart. To act as I have acted, to think as I have thought, requires the  maddening love of pleasure, mingled with the keen appetite of revenge, the  proud consciousness of power; droughts too intoxicating for the human heart to  bear, and yet retain the power to prevent. Their force has long passed  away&mdash;Age has no pleasures, wrinkles have no influence, revenge itself  dies away in impotent curses. Then comes remorse, with all its vipers, mixed  with vain regrets for the past, and despair for the future!&mdash;Then, when  all other strong impulses have ceased, we become like the fiends in hell, who  may feel remorse, but never repentance.&mdash;But thy words have awakened a new  soul within me&mdash;Well hast thou said, all is possible for those who dare to  die!&mdash;Thou hast shown me the means of revenge, and be assured I will  embrace them. It has hitherto shared this wasted bosom with other and with  rival passions&mdash;henceforward it shall possess me wholly, and thou thyself  shalt say, that, whatever was the life of Ulrica, her death well became the  daughter of the noble Torquil. There is a force without beleaguering this  accursed castle&mdash;hasten to lead them to the attack, and when thou shalt  see a red flag wave from the turret on the eastern angle of the donjon, press  the Normans hard&mdash;they will then have enough to do within, and you may win  the wall in spite both of bow and mangonel.&mdash;Begone, I pray  thee&mdash;follow thine own fate, and leave me to mine.&rdquo;          Cedric would have enquired farther into the purpose which she thus darkly  announced, but the stern voice of Front-de-Bœuf was heard, exclaiming,  &ldquo;Where tarries this loitering priest? By the scallop-shell of  Compostella, I will make a martyr of him, if he loiters here to hatch treason  among my domestics!&rdquo;          &ldquo;What a true prophet,&rdquo; said Ulrica, &ldquo;is an evil conscience!  But heed him not&mdash;out and to thy people&mdash;Cry your Saxon onslaught,  and let them sing their war-song of Rollo, if they will; vengeance shall bear a  burden to it.&rdquo;          As she thus spoke, she vanished through a private door, and Reginald  Front-de-Bœuf entered the apartment. Cedric, with some difficulty, compelled  himself to make obeisance to the haughty Baron, who returned his courtesy with  a slight inclination of the head.          &ldquo;Thy penitents, father, have made a long shrift&mdash;it is the better  for them, since it is the last they shall ever make. Hast thou prepared them  for death?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I found them,&rdquo; said Cedric, in such French as he could command,  &ldquo;expecting the worst, from the moment they knew into whose power they had  fallen.&rdquo;          &ldquo;How now, Sir Friar,&rdquo; replied Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;thy speech,  methinks, smacks of a Saxon tongue?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I was bred in the convent of St Withold of Burton,&rdquo; answered  Cedric.          &ldquo;Ay?&rdquo; said the Baron; &ldquo;it had been better for thee to have  been a Norman, and better for my purpose too; but need has no choice of  messengers. That St Withold&rsquo;s of Burton is an owlet&rsquo;s nest worth  the harrying. The day will soon come that the frock shall protect the Saxon as  little as the mail-coat.&rdquo;          &ldquo;God&rsquo;s will be done,&rdquo; said Cedric, in a voice tremulous with  passion, which Front-de-Bœuf imputed to fear.          &ldquo;I see,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;thou dreamest already that our men-at-arms  are in thy refectory and thy ale-vaults. But do me one cast of thy holy office,  and, come what list of others, thou shalt sleep as safe in thy cell as a snail  within his shell of proof.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Speak your commands,&rdquo; said Cedric, with suppressed emotion.          &ldquo;Follow me through this passage, then, that I may dismiss thee by the  postern.&rdquo;          And as he strode on his way before the supposed friar, Front-de-Bœuf thus  schooled him in the part which he desired he should act.          &ldquo;Thou seest, Sir Friar, yon herd of Saxon swine, who have dared to  environ this castle of Torquilstone&mdash;Tell them whatever thou hast a mind  of the weakness of this fortalice, or aught else that can detain them before it  for twenty-four hours. Meantime bear thou this scroll&mdash;But  soft&mdash;canst read, Sir Priest?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Not a jot I,&rdquo; answered Cedric, &ldquo;save on my breviary; and  then I know the characters, because I have the holy service by heart, praised  be Our Lady and St Withold!&rdquo;          &ldquo;The fitter messenger for my purpose.&mdash;Carry thou this scroll to the  castle of Philip de Malvoisin; say it cometh from me, and is written by the  Templar Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and that I pray him to send it to York with all  the speed man and horse can make. Meanwhile, tell him to doubt nothing, he  shall find us whole and sound behind our battlement&mdash;Shame on it, that we  should be compelled to hide thus by a pack of runagates, who are wont to fly  even at the flash of our pennons and the tramp of our horses! I say to thee,  priest, contrive some cast of thine art to keep the knaves where they are,  until our friends bring up their lances. My vengeance is awake, and she is a  falcon that slumbers not till she has been gorged.&rdquo;          &ldquo;By my patron saint,&rdquo; said Cedric, with deeper energy than became  his character, &ldquo;and by every saint who has lived and died in England,  your commands shall be obeyed! Not a Saxon shall stir from before these walls,  if I have art and influence to detain them there.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ha!&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;thou changest thy tone, Sir  Priest, and speakest brief and bold, as if thy heart were in the slaughter of  the Saxon herd; and yet thou art thyself of kindred to the swine?&rdquo;          Cedric was no ready practiser of the art of dissimulation, and would at this  moment have been much the better of a hint from Wamba&rsquo;s more fertile  brain. But necessity, according to the ancient proverb, sharpens invention, and  he muttered something under his cowl concerning the men in question being  excommunicated outlaws both to church and to kingdom.          &ldquo;&lsquo;Despardieux&rsquo;,&rdquo; answered Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;thou  hast spoken the very truth&mdash;I forgot that the knaves can strip a fat  abbot, as well as if they had been born south of yonder salt channel. Was it  not he of St Ives whom they tied to an oak-tree, and compelled to sing a mass  while they were rifling his mails and his wallets?&mdash;No, by our  Lady&mdash;that jest was played by Gualtier of Middleton, one of our own  companions-at-arms. But they were Saxons who robbed the chapel at St Bees of  cup, candlestick and chalice, were they not?&rdquo;          &ldquo;They were godless men,&rdquo; answered Cedric.          &ldquo;Ay, and they drank out all the good wine and ale that lay in store for  many a secret carousal, when ye pretend ye are but busied with vigils and  primes!&mdash;Priest, thou art bound to revenge such sacrilege.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am indeed bound to vengeance,&rdquo; murmured Cedric; &ldquo;Saint  Withold knows my heart.&rdquo;          Front-de-Bœuf, in the meanwhile, led the way to a postern, where, passing the  moat on a single plank, they reached a small barbican, or exterior defence,  which communicated with the open field by a well-fortified sallyport.          &ldquo;Begone, then; and if thou wilt do mine errand, and if thou return hither  when it is done, thou shalt see Saxon flesh cheap as ever was hog&rsquo;s in  the shambles of Sheffield. And, hark thee, thou seemest to be a jolly  confessor&mdash;come hither after the onslaught, and thou shalt have as much  Malvoisie as would drench thy whole convent.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Assuredly we shall meet again,&rdquo; answered Cedric.          &ldquo;Something in hand the whilst,&rdquo; continued the Norman; and, as they  parted at the postern door, he thrust into Cedric&rsquo;s reluctant hand a gold  byzant, adding, &ldquo;Remember, I will fly off both cowl and skin, if thou  failest in thy purpose.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And full leave will I give thee to do both,&rdquo; answered Cedric,  leaving the postern, and striding forth over the free field with a joyful step,  &ldquo;if, when we meet next, I deserve not better at thine  hand.&rdquo;&mdash;Turning then back towards the castle, he threw the piece of  gold towards the donor, exclaiming at the same time, &ldquo;False Norman, thy  money perish with thee!&rdquo;          Front-de-Bœuf heard the words imperfectly, but the action was  suspicious&mdash;&ldquo;Archers,&rdquo; he called to the warders on the outward  battlements, &ldquo;send me an arrow through yon monk&rsquo;s frock!&mdash;yet  stay,&rdquo; he said, as his retainers were bending their bows, &ldquo;it  avails not&mdash;we must thus far trust him since we have no better shift. I  think he dares not betray me&mdash;at the worst I can but treat with these  Saxon dogs whom I have safe in kennel.&mdash;Ho! Giles jailor, let them bring  Cedric of Rotherwood before me, and the other churl, his companion&mdash;him I  mean of Coningsburgh&mdash;Athelstane there, or what call they him? Their very  names are an encumbrance to a Norman knight&rsquo;s mouth, and have, as it  were, a flavour of bacon&mdash;Give me a stoup of wine, as jolly Prince John  said, that I may wash away the relish&mdash;place it in the armoury, and  thither lead the prisoners.&rdquo;          His commands were obeyed; and, upon entering that Gothic apartment, hung with  many spoils won by his own valour and that of his father, he found a flagon of  wine on the massive oaken table, and the two Saxon captives under the guard of  four of his dependants. Front-de-Bœuf took a long drought of wine, and then  addressed his prisoners;&mdash;for the manner in which Wamba drew the cap over  his face, the change of dress, the gloomy and broken light, and the  Baron&rsquo;s imperfect acquaintance with the features of Cedric, (who avoided  his Norman neighbours, and seldom stirred beyond his own domains,) prevented  him from discovering that the most important of his captives had made his  escape.          &ldquo;Gallants of England,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;how relish ye  your entertainment at Torquilstone?&mdash;Are ye yet aware what your  &lsquo;surquedy&rsquo; and &lsquo;outrecuidance&rsquo;   31   merit, for  scoffing at the entertainment of a prince of the House of Anjou?&mdash;Have ye  forgotten how ye requited the unmerited hospitality of the royal John? By God  and St Dennis, an ye pay not the richer ransom, I will hang ye up by the feet  from the iron bars of these windows, till the kites and hooded crows have made  skeletons of you!&mdash;Speak out, ye Saxon dogs&mdash;what bid ye for your  worthless lives?&mdash;How say you, you of Rotherwood?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Not a doit I,&rdquo; answered poor Wamba&mdash;&ldquo;and for hanging up  by the feet, my brain has been topsy-turvy, they say, ever since the biggin was  bound first round my head; so turning me upside down may peradventure restore  it again.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Saint Genevieve!&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;what have we got  here?&rdquo;          And with the back of his hand he struck Cedric&rsquo;s cap from the head of the  Jester, and throwing open his collar, discovered the fatal badge of servitude,  the silver collar round his neck.          &ldquo;Giles&mdash;Clement&mdash;dogs and varlets!&rdquo; exclaimed the furious  Norman, &ldquo;what have you brought me here?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I think I can tell you,&rdquo; said De Bracy, who just entered the  apartment. &ldquo;This is Cedric&rsquo;s clown, who fought so manful a skirmish  with Isaac of York about a question of precedence.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I shall settle it for them both,&rdquo; replied Front-de-Bœuf;  &ldquo;they shall hang on the same gallows, unless his master and this boar of  Coningsburgh will pay well for their lives. Their wealth is the least they can  surrender; they must also carry off with them the swarms that are besetting the  castle, subscribe a surrender of their pretended immunities, and live under us  as serfs and vassals; too happy if, in the new world that is about to begin, we  leave them the breath of their nostrils.&mdash;Go,&rdquo; said he to two of his  attendants, &ldquo;fetch me the right Cedric hither, and I pardon your error  for once; the rather that you but mistook a fool for a Saxon franklin.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay, but,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;your chivalrous excellency will find  there are more fools than franklins among us.&rdquo;          &ldquo;What means the knave?&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, looking towards his  followers, who, lingering and loath, faltered forth their belief, that if this  were not Cedric who was there in presence, they knew not what was become of  him.          &ldquo;Saints of Heaven!&rdquo; exclaimed De Bracy, &ldquo;he must have escaped  in the monk&rsquo;s garments!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Fiends of hell!&rdquo; echoed Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;it was then the  boar of Rotherwood whom I ushered to the postern, and dismissed with my own  hands!&mdash;And thou,&rdquo; he said to Wamba, &ldquo;whose folly could  overreach the wisdom of idiots yet more gross than thyself&mdash;I will give  thee holy orders&mdash;I will shave thy crown for thee!&mdash;Here, let them  tear the scalp from his head, and then pitch him headlong from the  battlements&mdash;Thy trade is to jest, canst thou jest now?&rdquo;          &ldquo;You deal with me better than your word, noble knight,&rdquo; whimpered  forth poor Wamba, whose habits of buffoonery were not to be overcome even by  the immediate prospect of death; &ldquo;if you give me the red cap you propose,  out of a simple monk you will make a cardinal.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The poor wretch,&rdquo; said De Bracy, &ldquo;is resolved to die in his  vocation.&mdash;Front-de-Bœuf, you shall not slay him. Give him to me to make  sport for my Free Companions.&mdash;How sayst thou, knave? Wilt thou take heart  of grace, and go to the wars with me?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay, with my master&rsquo;s leave,&rdquo; said Wamba; &ldquo;for, look  you, I must not slip collar&rdquo; (and he touched that which he wore)  &ldquo;without his permission.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Oh, a Norman saw will soon cut a Saxon collar.&rdquo; said De Bracy.          &ldquo;Ay, noble sir,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;and thence goes the  proverb&mdash;          &lsquo;Norman saw on English oak,   On English neck a Norman yoke;   Norman spoon in English dish,   And England ruled as Normans wish;   Blithe world to England never will be more,   Till England&rsquo;s rid of all the four.&rsquo;&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou dost well, De Bracy,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;to stand  there listening to a fool&rsquo;s jargon, when destruction is gaping for us!  Seest thou not we are overreached, and that our proposed mode of communicating  with our friends without has been disconcerted by this same motley gentleman  thou art so fond to brother? What views have we to expect but instant  storm?&rdquo;          &ldquo;To the battlements then,&rdquo; said De Bracy; &ldquo;when didst thou  ever see me the graver for the thoughts of battle? Call the Templar yonder, and  let him fight but half so well for his life as he has done for his  Order&mdash;Make thou to the walls thyself with thy huge body&mdash;Let me do  my poor endeavour in my own way, and I tell thee the Saxon outlaws may as well  attempt to scale the clouds, as the castle of Torquilstone; or, if you will  treat with the banditti, why not employ the mediation of this worthy franklin,  who seems in such deep contemplation of the wine-flagon?&mdash;Here,  Saxon,&rdquo; he continued, addressing Athelstane, and handing the cup to him,  &ldquo;rinse thy throat with that noble liquor, and rouse up thy soul to say  what thou wilt do for thy liberty.&rdquo;          &ldquo;What a man of mould may,&rdquo; answered Athelstane, &ldquo;providing it  be what a man of manhood ought.&mdash;Dismiss me free, with my companions, and  I will pay a ransom of a thousand marks.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And wilt moreover assure us the retreat of that scum of mankind who are  swarming around the castle, contrary to God&rsquo;s peace and the  king&rsquo;s?&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf.          &ldquo;In so far as I can,&rdquo; answered Athelstane, &ldquo;I will withdraw  them; and I fear not but that my father Cedric will do his best to assist  me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;We are agreed then,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf&mdash;&ldquo;thou and  they are to be set at freedom, and peace is to be on both sides, for payment of  a thousand marks. It is a trifling ransom, Saxon, and thou wilt owe gratitude  to the moderation which accepts of it in exchange of your persons. But mark,  this extends not to the Jew Isaac.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nor to the Jew Isaac&rsquo;s daughter,&rdquo; said the Templar, who had  now joined them.          &ldquo;Neither,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;belong to this Saxon&rsquo;s  company.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I were unworthy to be called Christian, if they did,&rdquo; replied  Athelstane: &ldquo;deal with the unbelievers as ye list.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Neither does the ransom include the Lady Rowena,&rdquo; said De Bracy.  &ldquo;It shall never be said I was scared out of a fair prize without striking  a blow for it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Neither,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;does our treaty refer to  this wretched Jester, whom I retain, that I may make him an example to every  knave who turns jest into earnest.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The Lady Rowena,&rdquo; answered Athelstane, with the most steady  countenance, &ldquo;is my affianced bride. I will be drawn by wild horses  before I consent to part with her. The slave Wamba has this day saved the life  of my father Cedric&mdash;I will lose mine ere a hair of his head be  injured.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thy affianced bride?&mdash;The Lady Rowena the affianced bride of a  vassal like thee?&rdquo; said De Bracy; &ldquo;Saxon, thou dreamest that the  days of thy seven kingdoms are returned again. I tell thee, the Princes of the  House of Anjou confer not their wards on men of such lineage as thine.&rdquo;          &ldquo;My lineage, proud Norman,&rdquo; replied Athelstane, &ldquo;is drawn  from a source more pure and ancient than that of a beggarly Frenchman, whose  living is won by selling the blood of the thieves whom he assembles under his  paltry standard. Kings were my ancestors, strong in war and wise in council,  who every day feasted in their hall more hundreds than thou canst number  individual followers; whose names have been sung by minstrels, and their laws  recorded by Wittenagemotes; whose bones were interred amid the prayers of  saints, and over whose tombs minsters have been builded.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou hast it, De Bracy,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, well pleased with  the rebuff which his companion had received; &ldquo;the Saxon hath hit thee  fairly.&rdquo;          &ldquo;As fairly as a captive can strike,&rdquo; said De Bracy, with apparent  carelessness; &ldquo;for he whose hands are tied should have his tongue at  freedom.&mdash;But thy glibness of reply, comrade,&rdquo; rejoined he, speaking  to Athelstane, &ldquo;will not win the freedom of the Lady Rowena.&rdquo;          To this Athelstane, who had already made a longer speech than was his custom to  do on any topic, however interesting, returned no answer. The conversation was  interrupted by the arrival of a menial, who announced that a monk demanded  admittance at the postern gate.          &ldquo;In the name of Saint Bennet, the prince of these bull-beggars,&rdquo;  said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;have we a real monk this time, or another impostor?  Search him, slaves&mdash;for an ye suffer a second impostor to be palmed upon  you, I will have your eyes torn out, and hot coals put into the sockets.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Let me endure the extremity of your anger, my lord,&rdquo; said Giles,  &ldquo;if this be not a real shaveling. Your squire Jocelyn knows him well, and  will vouch him to be brother Ambrose, a monk in attendance upon the Prior of  Jorvaulx.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Admit him,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf; &ldquo;most likely he brings us  news from his jovial master. Surely the devil keeps holiday, and the priests  are relieved from duty, that they are strolling thus wildly through the  country. Remove these prisoners; and, Saxon, think on what thou hast  heard.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I claim,&rdquo; said Athelstane, &ldquo;an honourable imprisonment, with  due care of my board and of my couch, as becomes my rank, and as is due to one  who is in treaty for ransom. Moreover, I hold him that deems himself the best  of you, bound to answer to me with his body for this aggression on my freedom.  This defiance hath already been sent to thee by thy sewer; thou underliest it,  and art bound to answer me&mdash;There lies my glove.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I answer not the challenge of my prisoner,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf;  &ldquo;nor shalt thou, Maurice de Bracy.&mdash;Giles,&rdquo; he continued,  &ldquo;hang the franklin&rsquo;s glove upon the tine of yonder branched  antlers: there shall it remain until he is a free man. Should he then presume  to demand it, or to affirm he was unlawfully made my prisoner, by the belt of  Saint Christopher, he will speak to one who hath never refused to meet a foe on  foot or on horseback, alone or with his vassals at his back!&rdquo;          The Saxon prisoners were accordingly removed, just as they introduced the monk  Ambrose, who appeared to be in great perturbation.          &ldquo;This is the real &lsquo;Deus vobiscum&rsquo;,&rdquo; said Wamba, as he  passed the reverend brother; &ldquo;the others were but counterfeits.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Holy Mother,&rdquo; said the monk, as he addressed the assembled  knights, &ldquo;I am at last safe and in Christian keeping!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Safe thou art,&rdquo; replied De Bracy; &ldquo;and for Christianity,  here is the stout Baron Reginald Front-de-Bœuf, whose utter abomination is a  Jew; and the good Knight Templar, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, whose trade is to  slay Saracens&mdash;If these are not good marks of Christianity, I know no  other which they bear about them.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ye are friends and allies of our reverend father in God, Aymer, Prior of  Jorvaulx,&rdquo; said the monk, without noticing the tone of De Bracy&rsquo;s  reply; &ldquo;ye owe him aid both by knightly faith and holy charity; for what  saith the blessed Saint Augustin, in his treatise &lsquo;De Civitate  Dei&rsquo;&mdash;-&rdquo;          &ldquo;What saith the devil!&rdquo; interrupted Front-de-Bœuf; &ldquo;or  rather what dost thou say, Sir Priest? We have little time to hear texts from  the holy fathers.&rdquo;          &ldquo;&lsquo;Sancta Maria!&rsquo;&rdquo; ejaculated Father Ambrose, &ldquo;how  prompt to ire are these unhallowed laymen!&mdash;But be it known to you, brave  knights, that certain murderous caitiffs, casting behind them fear of God, and  reverence of his church, and not regarding the bull of the holy see, &lsquo;Si  quis, suadende Diabolo&rsquo;&mdash;&rdquo;          &ldquo;Brother priest,&rdquo; said the Templar, &ldquo;all this we know or  guess at&mdash;tell us plainly, is thy master, the Prior, made prisoner, and to  whom?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Surely,&rdquo; said Ambrose, &ldquo;he is in the hands of the men of  Belial, infesters of these woods, and contemners of the holy text, &lsquo;Touch  not mine anointed, and do my prophets naught of evil.&rsquo;&rdquo;          &ldquo;Here is a new argument for our swords, sirs,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf,  turning to his companions; &ldquo;and so, instead of reaching us any  assistance, the Prior of Jorvaulx requests aid at our hands? a man is well  helped of these lazy churchmen when he hath most to do!&mdash;But speak out,  priest, and say at once, what doth thy master expect from us?&rdquo;          &ldquo;So please you,&rdquo; said Ambrose, &ldquo;violent hands having been  imposed on my reverend superior, contrary to the holy ordinance which I did  already quote, and the men of Belial having rifled his mails and budgets, and  stripped him of two hundred marks of pure refined gold, they do yet demand of  him a large sum beside, ere they will suffer him to depart from their  uncircumcised hands. Wherefore the reverend father in God prays you, as his  dear friends, to rescue him, either by paying down the ransom at which they  hold him, or by force of arms, at your best discretion.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The foul fiend quell the Prior!&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf; &ldquo;his  morning&rsquo;s drought has been a deep one. When did thy master hear of a  Norman baron unbuckling his purse to relieve a churchman, whose bags are ten  times as weighty as ours?&mdash;And how can we do aught by valour to free him,  that are cooped up here by ten times our number, and expect an assault every  moment?&rdquo;          &ldquo;And that was what I was about to tell you,&rdquo; said the monk,  &ldquo;had your hastiness allowed me time. But, God help me, I am old, and  these foul onslaughts distract an aged man&rsquo;s brain. Nevertheless, it is  of verity that they assemble a camp, and raise a bank against the walls of this  castle.&rdquo;          &ldquo;To the battlements!&rdquo; cried De Bracy, &ldquo;and let us mark what  these knaves do without;&rdquo; and so saying, he opened a latticed window  which led to a sort of bartisan or projecting balcony, and immediately called  from thence to those in the apartment&mdash;&ldquo;Saint Dennis, but the old  monk hath brought true tidings!&mdash;They bring forward mantelets and  pavisses,   32   and the archers muster on the skirts  of the wood like a dark cloud before a hailstorm.&rdquo;          Reginald Front-de-Bœuf also looked out upon the field, and immediately  snatched his bugle; and, after winding a long and loud blast, commanded his men  to their posts on the walls.          &ldquo;De Bracy, look to the eastern side, where the walls are  lowest&mdash;Noble Bois-Guilbert, thy trade hath well taught thee how to attack  and defend, look thou to the western side&mdash;I myself will take post at the  barbican. Yet, do not confine your exertions to any one spot, noble  friends!&mdash;we must this day be everywhere, and multiply ourselves, were it  possible, so as to carry by our presence succour and relief wherever the attack  is hottest. Our numbers are few, but activity and courage may supply that  defect, since we have only to do with rascal clowns.&rdquo;          &ldquo;But, noble knights,&rdquo; exclaimed Father Ambrose, amidst the bustle  and confusion occasioned by the preparations for defence, &ldquo;will none of  ye hear the message of the reverend father in God Aymer, Prior of  Jorvaulx?&mdash;I beseech thee to hear me, noble Sir Reginald!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Go patter thy petitions to heaven,&rdquo; said the fierce Norman,  &ldquo;for we on earth have no time to listen to them.&mdash;Ho! there, Anselm  I see that seething pitch and oil are ready to pour on the heads of these  audacious traitors&mdash;Look that the cross-bowmen lack not bolts.   33  &mdash;Fling abroad my banner with the  old bull&rsquo;s head&mdash;the knaves shall soon find with whom they have to  do this day!&rdquo;          &ldquo;But, noble sir,&rdquo; continued the monk, persevering in his endeavours  to draw attention, &ldquo;consider my vow of obedience, and let me discharge  myself of my Superior&rsquo;s errand.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Away with this prating dotard,&rdquo; said Front-de Bœuf, &ldquo;lock  him up in the chapel, to tell his beads till the broil be over. It will be a  new thing to the saints in Torquilstone to hear aves and paters; they have not  been so honoured, I trow, since they were cut out of stone.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Blaspheme not the holy saints, Sir Reginald,&rdquo; said De Bracy,  &ldquo;we shall have need of their aid to-day before yon rascal rout  disband.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I expect little aid from their hand,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf,  &ldquo;unless we were to hurl them from the battlements on the heads of the  villains. There is a huge lumbering Saint Christopher yonder, sufficient to  bear a whole company to the earth.&rdquo;          The Templar had in the meantime been looking out on the proceedings of the  besiegers, with rather more attention than the brutal Front-de-Bœuf or his  giddy companion.          &ldquo;By the faith of mine order,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;these men approach  with more touch of discipline than could have been judged, however they come by  it. See ye how dexterously they avail themselves of every cover which a tree or  bush affords, and shun exposing themselves to the shot of our cross-bows? I spy  neither banner nor pennon among them, and yet will I gage my golden chain, that  they are led on by some noble knight or gentleman, skilful in the practice of  wars.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I espy him,&rdquo; said De Bracy; &ldquo;I see the waving of a  knight&rsquo;s crest, and the gleam of his armour. See yon tall man in the  black mail, who is busied marshalling the farther troop of the rascaille  yeomen&mdash;by Saint Dennis, I hold him to be the same whom we called  &lsquo;Le Noir Faineant&rsquo;, who overthrew thee, Front-de-Bœuf, in the  lists at Ashby.&rdquo;          &ldquo;So much the better,&rdquo; said Front-de-Bœuf, &ldquo;that he comes  here to give me my revenge. Some hilding fellow he must be, who dared not stay  to assert his claim to the tourney prize which chance had assigned him. I  should in vain have sought for him where knights and nobles seek their foes,  and right glad am I he hath here shown himself among yon villain  yeomanry.&rdquo;          The demonstrations of the enemy&rsquo;s immediate approach cut off all farther  discourse. Each knight repaired to his post, and at the head of the few  followers whom they were able to muster, and who were in numbers inadequate to  defend the whole extent of the walls, they awaited with calm determination the  threatened assault.                     CHAPTER XXVIII        This wandering race, sever&rsquo;d from other men,   Boast yet their intercourse with human arts;   The seas, the woods, the deserts, which they haunt,   Find them acquainted with their secret treasures:   And unregarded herbs, and flowers, and blossoms,   Display undreamt-of powers when gather&rsquo;d by them.          T HE  J EW           Our history must needs retrograde for the space of a few pages, to inform the  reader of certain passages material to his understanding the rest of this  important narrative. His own intelligence may indeed have easily anticipated  that, when Ivanhoe sunk down, and seemed abandoned by all the world, it was the  importunity of Rebecca which prevailed on her father to have the gallant young  warrior transported from the lists to the house which for the time the Jews  inhabited in the suburbs of Ashby.          It would not have been difficult to have persuaded Isaac to this step in any  other circumstances, for his disposition was kind and grateful. But he had also  the prejudices and scrupulous timidity of his persecuted people, and those were  to be conquered.          &ldquo;Holy Abraham!&rdquo; he exclaimed, &ldquo;he is a good youth, and my  heart bleeds to see the gore trickle down his rich embroidered hacqueton, and  his corslet of goodly price&mdash;but to carry him to our house!&mdash;damsel,  hast thou well considered?&mdash;he is a Christian, and by our law we may not  deal with the stranger and Gentile, save for the advantage of our  commerce.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Speak not so, my dear father,&rdquo; replied Rebecca; &ldquo;we may not  indeed mix with them in banquet and in jollity; but in wounds and in misery,  the Gentile becometh the Jew&rsquo;s brother.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I would I knew what the Rabbi Jacob Ben Tudela would opine on it,&rdquo;  replied Isaac;&mdash;&ldquo;nevertheless, the good youth must not bleed to  death. Let Seth and Reuben bear him to Ashby.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, let them place him in my litter,&rdquo; said Rebecca; &ldquo;I will  mount one of the palfreys.&rdquo;          &ldquo;That were to expose thee to the gaze of those dogs of Ishmael and of  Edom,&rdquo; whispered Isaac, with a suspicious glance towards the crowd of  knights and squires. But Rebecca was already busied in carrying her charitable  purpose into effect, and listed not what he said, until Isaac, seizing the  sleeve of her mantle, again exclaimed, in a hurried voice&mdash;&ldquo;Beard of  Aaron!&mdash;what if the youth perish!&mdash;if he die in our custody, shall we  not be held guilty of his blood, and be torn to pieces by the multitude?&rdquo;          &ldquo;He will not die, my father,&rdquo; said Rebecca, gently extricating  herself from the grasp of Isaac &ldquo;he will not die unless we abandon him;  and if so, we are indeed answerable for his blood to God and to man.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; said Isaac, releasing his hold, &ldquo;it grieveth me as  much to see the drops of his blood, as if they were so many golden byzants from  mine own purse; and I well know, that the lessons of Miriam, daughter of the  Rabbi Manasses of Byzantium whose soul is in Paradise, have made thee skilful  in the art of healing, and that thou knowest the craft of herbs, and the force  of elixirs. Therefore, do as thy mind giveth thee&mdash;thou art a good damsel,  a blessing, and a crown, and a song of rejoicing unto me and unto my house, and  unto the people of my fathers.&rdquo;          The apprehensions of Isaac, however, were not ill founded; and the generous and  grateful benevolence of his daughter exposed her, on her return to Ashby, to  the unhallowed gaze of Brian de Bois-Guilbert. The Templar twice passed and  repassed them on the road, fixing his bold and ardent look on the beautiful  Jewess; and we have already seen the consequences of the admiration which her  charms excited when accident threw her into the power of that unprincipled  voluptuary.          Rebecca lost no time in causing the patient to be transported to their  temporary dwelling, and proceeded with her own hands to examine and to bind up  his wounds. The youngest reader of romances and romantic ballads, must  recollect how often the females, during the dark ages, as they are called, were  initiated into the mysteries of surgery, and how frequently the gallant knight  submitted the wounds of his person to her cure, whose eyes had yet more deeply  penetrated his heart.          But the Jews, both male and female, possessed and practised the medical science  in all its branches, and the monarchs and powerful barons of the time  frequently committed themselves to the charge of some experienced sage among  this despised people, when wounded or in sickness. The aid of the Jewish  physicians was not the less eagerly sought after, though a general belief  prevailed among the Christians, that the Jewish Rabbins were deeply acquainted  with the occult sciences, and particularly with the cabalistical art, which had  its name and origin in the studies of the sages of Israel. Neither did the  Rabbins disown such acquaintance with supernatural arts, which added nothing  (for what could add aught?) to the hatred with which their nation was regarded,  while it diminished the contempt with which that malevolence was mingled. A  Jewish magician might be the subject of equal abhorrence with a Jewish usurer,  but he could not be equally despised. It is besides probable, considering the  wonderful cures they are said to have performed, that the Jews possessed some  secrets of the healing art peculiar to themselves, and which, with the  exclusive spirit arising out of their condition, they took great care to  conceal from the Christians amongst whom they dwelt.          The beautiful Rebecca had been heedfully brought up in all the knowledge proper  to her nation, which her apt and powerful mind had retained, arranged, and  enlarged, in the course of a progress beyond her years, her sex, and even the  age in which she lived. Her knowledge of medicine and of the healing art had  been acquired under an aged Jewess, the daughter of one of their most  celebrated doctors, who loved Rebecca as her own child, and was believed to  have communicated to her secrets, which had been left to herself by her sage  father at the same time, and under the same circumstances. The fate of Miriam  had indeed been to fall a sacrifice to the fanaticism of the times; but her  secrets had survived in her apt pupil.          Rebecca, thus endowed with knowledge as with beauty, was universally revered  and admired by her own tribe, who almost regarded her as one of those gifted  women mentioned in the sacred history. Her father himself, out of reverence for  her talents, which involuntarily mingled itself with his unbounded affection,  permitted the maiden a greater liberty than was usually indulged to those of  her sex by the habits of her people, and was, as we have just seen, frequently  guided by her opinion, even in preference to his own.          When Ivanhoe reached the habitation of Isaac, he was still in a state of  unconsciousness, owing to the profuse loss of blood which had taken place  during his exertions in the lists. Rebecca examined the wound, and having  applied to it such vulnerary remedies as her art prescribed, informed her  father that if fever could be averted, of which the great bleeding rendered her  little apprehensive, and if the healing balsam of Miriam retained its virtue,  there was nothing to fear for his guest&rsquo;s life, and that he might with  safety travel to York with them on the ensuing day. Isaac looked a little blank  at this annunciation. His charity would willingly have stopped short at Ashby,  or at most would have left the wounded Christian to be tended in the house  where he was residing at present, with an assurance to the Hebrew to whom it  belonged, that all expenses should be duly discharged. To this, however,  Rebecca opposed many reasons, of which we shall only mention two that had  peculiar weight with Isaac. The one was, that she would on no account put the  phial of precious balsam into the hands of another physician even of her own  tribe, lest that valuable mystery should be discovered; the other, that this  wounded knight, Wilfred of Ivanhoe, was an intimate favourite of Richard  Cœur-de-Lion, and that, in case the monarch should return, Isaac, who had  supplied his brother John with treasure to prosecute his rebellious purposes,  would stand in no small need of a powerful protector who enjoyed  Richard&rsquo;s favour.          &ldquo;Thou art speaking but sooth, Rebecca,&rdquo; said Isaac, giving way to  these weighty arguments&mdash;&ldquo;it were an offending of Heaven to betray  the secrets of the blessed Miriam; for the good which Heaven giveth, is not  rashly to be squandered upon others, whether it be talents of gold and shekels  of silver, or whether it be the secret mysteries of a wise  physician&mdash;assuredly they should be preserved to those to whom Providence  hath vouchsafed them. And him whom the Nazarenes of England call the  Lion&rsquo;s Heart, assuredly it were better for me to fall into the hands of a  strong lion of Idumea than into his, if he shall have got assurance of my  dealing with his brother. Wherefore I will lend ear to thy counsel, and this  youth shall journey with us unto York, and our house shall be as a home to him  until his wounds shall be healed. And if he of the Lion Heart shall return to  the land, as is now noised abroad, then shall this Wilfred of Ivanhoe be unto  me as a wall of defence, when the king&rsquo;s displeasure shall burn high  against thy father. And if he doth not return, this Wilfred may natheless repay  us our charges when he shall gain treasure by the strength of his spear and of  his sword, even as he did yesterday and this day also. For the youth is a good  youth, and keepeth the day which he appointeth, and restoreth that which he  borroweth, and succoureth the Israelite, even the child of my father&rsquo;s  house, when he is encompassed by strong thieves and sons of Belial.&rdquo;          It was not until evening was nearly closed that Ivanhoe was restored to  consciousness of his situation. He awoke from a broken slumber, under the  confused impressions which are naturally attendant on the recovery from a state  of insensibility. He was unable for some time to recall exactly to memory the  circumstances which had preceded his fall in the lists, or to make out any  connected chain of the events in which he had been engaged upon the yesterday.  A sense of wounds and injury, joined to great weakness and exhaustion, was  mingled with the recollection of blows dealt and received, of steeds rushing  upon each other, overthrowing and overthrown&mdash;of shouts and clashing of  arms, and all the heady tumult of a confused fight. An effort to draw aside the  curtain of his couch was in some degree successful, although rendered difficult  by the pain of his wound.          To his great surprise he found himself in a room magnificently furnished, but  having cushions instead of chairs to rest upon, and in other respects partaking  so much of Oriental costume, that he began to doubt whether he had not, during  his sleep, been transported back again to the land of Palestine. The impression  was increased, when, the tapestry being drawn aside, a female form, dressed in  a rich habit, which partook more of the Eastern taste than that of Europe,  glided through the door which it concealed, and was followed by a swarthy  domestic.          As the wounded knight was about to address this fair apparition, she imposed  silence by placing her slender finger upon her ruby lips, while the attendant,  approaching him, proceeded to uncover Ivanhoe&rsquo;s side, and the lovely  Jewess satisfied herself that the bandage was in its place, and the wound doing  well. She performed her task with a graceful and dignified simplicity and  modesty, which might, even in more civilized days, have served to redeem it  from whatever might seem repugnant to female delicacy. The idea of so young and  beautiful a person engaged in attendance on a sick-bed, or in dressing the  wound of one of a different sex, was melted away and lost in that of a  beneficent being contributing her effectual aid to relieve pain, and to avert  the stroke of death. Rebecca&rsquo;s few and brief directions were given in the  Hebrew language to the old domestic; and he, who had been frequently her  assistant in similar cases, obeyed them without reply.          The accents of an unknown tongue, however harsh they might have sounded when  uttered by another, had, coming from the beautiful Rebecca, the romantic and  pleasing effect which fancy ascribes to the charms pronounced by some  beneficent fairy, unintelligible, indeed, to the ear, but, from the sweetness  of utterance, and benignity of aspect, which accompanied them, touching and  affecting to the heart. Without making an attempt at further question, Ivanhoe  suffered them in silence to take the measures they thought most proper for his  recovery; and it was not until those were completed, and this kind physician  about to retire, that his curiosity could no longer be  suppressed.&mdash;&ldquo;Gentle maiden,&rdquo; he began in the Arabian tongue,  with which his Eastern travels had rendered him familiar, and which he thought  most likely to be understood by the turban&rsquo;d and caftan&rsquo;d damsel  who stood before him&mdash;&ldquo;I pray you, gentle maiden, of your  courtesy&mdash;-&rdquo;          But here he was interrupted by his fair physician, a smile which she could  scarce suppress dimpling for an instant a face, whose general expression was  that of contemplative melancholy. &ldquo;I am of England, Sir Knight, and speak  the English tongue, although my dress and my lineage belong to another  climate.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Noble damsel,&rdquo;&mdash;again the Knight of Ivanhoe began; and again  Rebecca hastened to interrupt him.          &ldquo;Bestow not on me, Sir Knight,&rdquo; she said, &ldquo;the epithet of  noble. It is well you should speedily know that your handmaiden is a poor  Jewess, the daughter of that Isaac of York, to whom you were so lately a good  and kind lord. It well becomes him, and those of his household, to render to  you such careful tendance as your present state necessarily demands.&rdquo;          I know not whether the fair Rowena would have been altogether satisfied with  the species of emotion with which her devoted knight had hitherto gazed on the  beautiful features, and fair form, and lustrous eyes, of the lovely Rebecca;  eyes whose brilliancy was shaded, and, as it were, mellowed, by the fringe of  her long silken eyelashes, and which a minstrel would have compared to the  evening star darting its rays through a bower of jessamine. But Ivanhoe was too  good a Catholic to retain the same class of feelings towards a Jewess. This  Rebecca had foreseen, and for this very purpose she had hastened to mention her  father&rsquo;s name and lineage; yet&mdash;for the fair and wise daughter of  Isaac was not without a touch of female weakness&mdash;she could not but sigh  internally when the glance of respectful admiration, not altogether unmixed  with tenderness, with which Ivanhoe had hitherto regarded his unknown  benefactress, was exchanged at once for a manner cold, composed, and collected,  and fraught with no deeper feeling than that which expressed a grateful sense  of courtesy received from an unexpected quarter, and from one of an inferior  race. It was not that Ivanhoe&rsquo;s former carriage expressed more than that  general devotional homage which youth always pays to beauty; yet it was  mortifying that one word should operate as a spell to remove poor Rebecca, who  could not be supposed altogether ignorant of her title to such homage, into a  degraded class, to whom it could not be honourably rendered.          But the gentleness and candour of Rebecca&rsquo;s nature imputed no fault to  Ivanhoe for sharing in the universal prejudices of his age and religion. On the  contrary the fair Jewess, though sensible her patient now regarded her as one  of a race of reprobation, with whom it was disgraceful to hold any beyond the  most necessary intercourse, ceased not to pay the same patient and devoted  attention to his safety and convalescence. She informed him of the necessity  they were under of removing to York, and of her father&rsquo;s resolution to  transport him thither, and tend him in his own house until his health should be  restored. Ivanhoe expressed great repugnance to this plan, which he grounded on  unwillingness to give farther trouble to his benefactors.          &ldquo;Was there not,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;in Ashby, or near it, some Saxon  franklin, or even some wealthy peasant, who would endure the burden of a  wounded countryman&rsquo;s residence with him until he should be again able to  bear his armour?&mdash;Was there no convent of Saxon endowment, where he could  be received?&mdash;Or could he not be transported as far as Burton, where he  was sure to find hospitality with Waltheoff, the Abbot of St Withold&rsquo;s,  to whom he was related?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Any, the worst of these harbourages,&rdquo; said Rebecca, with a  melancholy smile, &ldquo;would unquestionably be more fitting for your  residence than the abode of a despised Jew; yet, Sir Knight, unless you would  dismiss your physician, you cannot change your lodging. Our nation, as you well  know, can cure wounds, though we deal not in inflicting them; and in our own  family, in particular, are secrets which have been handed down since the days  of Solomon, and of which you have already experienced the advantages. No  Nazarene&mdash;I crave your forgiveness, Sir Knight&mdash;no Christian leech,  within the four seas of Britain, could enable you to bear your corslet within a  month.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And how soon wilt THOU enable me to brook it?&rdquo; said Ivanhoe,  impatiently.          &ldquo;Within eight days, if thou wilt be patient and conformable to my  directions,&rdquo; replied Rebecca.          &ldquo;By Our Blessed Lady,&rdquo; said Wilfred, &ldquo;if it be not a sin to  name her here, it is no time for me or any true knight to be bedridden; and if  thou accomplish thy promise, maiden, I will pay thee with my casque full of  crowns, come by them as I may.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I will accomplish my promise,&rdquo; said Rebecca, &ldquo;and thou shalt  bear thine armour on the eighth day from hence, if thou will grant me but one  boon in the stead of the silver thou dost promise me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;If it be within my power, and such as a true Christian knight may yield  to one of thy people,&rdquo; replied Ivanhoe, &ldquo;I will grant thy boon  blithely and thankfully.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; answered Rebecca, &ldquo;I will but pray of thee to believe  henceforward that a Jew may do good service to a Christian, without desiring  other guerdon than the blessing of the Great Father who made both Jew and  Gentile.&rdquo;          &ldquo;It were sin to doubt it, maiden,&rdquo; replied Ivanhoe; &ldquo;and I  repose myself on thy skill without further scruple or question, well trusting  you will enable me to bear my corslet on the eighth day.
