At  length the volumes of smoke which rolled into the apartment&mdash;the cries for  water, which were heard even above the din of the battle made them sensible of  the progress of this new danger.          &ldquo;The castle burns,&rdquo; said Rebecca; &ldquo;it burns!&mdash;What can  we do to save ourselves?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Fly, Rebecca, and save thine own life,&rdquo; said Ivanhoe, &ldquo;for  no human aid can avail me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I will not fly,&rdquo; answered Rebecca; &ldquo;we will be saved or  perish together&mdash;And yet, great God!&mdash;my father, my father&mdash;what  will be his fate!&rdquo;          At this moment the door of the apartment flew open, and the Templar presented  himself,&mdash;a ghastly figure, for his gilded armour was broken and bloody,  and the plume was partly shorn away, partly burnt from his casque. &ldquo;I  have found thee,&rdquo; said he to Rebecca; &ldquo;thou shalt prove I will keep  my word to share weal and woe with thee&mdash;There is but one path to safety,  I have cut my way through fifty dangers to point it to thee&mdash;up, and  instantly follow me!&rdquo;   38            &ldquo;Alone,&rdquo; answered Rebecca, &ldquo;I will not follow thee. If thou  wert born of woman&mdash;if thou hast but a touch of human charity in  thee&mdash;if thy heart be not hard as thy breastplate&mdash;save my aged  father&mdash;save this wounded knight!&rdquo;          &ldquo;A knight,&rdquo; answered the Templar, with his characteristic calmness,  &ldquo;a knight, Rebecca, must encounter his fate, whether it meet him in the  shape of sword or flame&mdash;and who recks how or where a Jew meets with  his?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Savage warrior,&rdquo; said Rebecca, &ldquo;rather will I perish in the  flames than accept safety from thee!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou shalt not choose, Rebecca&mdash;once didst thou foil me, but never  mortal did so twice.&rdquo;          So saying, he seized on the terrified maiden, who filled the air with her  shrieks, and bore her out of the room in his arms in spite of her cries, and  without regarding the menaces and defiance which Ivanhoe thundered against him.  &ldquo;Hound of the Temple&mdash;stain to thine Order&mdash;set free the  damsel! Traitor of Bois-Guilbert, it is Ivanhoe commands thee!&mdash;Villain, I  will have thy heart&rsquo;s blood!&rdquo;                      &ldquo;I had not found thee, Wilfred,&rdquo; said the Black Knight, who at that  instant entered the apartment, &ldquo;but for thy shouts.&rdquo;          &ldquo;If thou be&rsquo;st true knight,&rdquo; said Wilfred, &ldquo;think not  of me&mdash;pursue yon ravisher&mdash;save the Lady Rowena&mdash;look to the  noble Cedric!&rdquo;          &ldquo;In their turn,&rdquo; answered he of the Fetterlock, &ldquo;but thine is  first.&rdquo;          And seizing upon Ivanhoe, he bore him off with as much ease as the Templar had  carried off Rebecca, rushed with him to the postern, and having there delivered  his burden to the care of two yeomen, he again entered the castle to assist in  the rescue of the other prisoners.          One turret was now in bright flames, which flashed out furiously from window  and shot-hole. But in other parts, the great thickness of the walls and the  vaulted roofs of the apartments, resisted the progress of the flames, and there  the rage of man still triumphed, as the scarce more dreadful element held  mastery elsewhere; for the besiegers pursued the defenders of the castle from  chamber to chamber, and satiated in their blood the vengeance which had long  animated them against the soldiers of the tyrant Front-de-Bœuf. Most of the  garrison resisted to the uttermost&mdash;few of them asked quarter&mdash;none  received it. The air was filled with groans and clashing of arms&mdash;the  floors were slippery with the blood of despairing and expiring wretches.          Through this scene of confusion, Cedric rushed in quest of Rowena, while the  faithful Gurth, following him closely through the &ldquo;melee&rdquo;,  neglected his own safety while he strove to avert the blows that were aimed at  his master. The noble Saxon was so fortunate as to reach his ward&rsquo;s  apartment just as she had abandoned all hope of safety, and, with a crucifix  clasped in agony to her bosom, sat in expectation of instant death. He  committed her to the charge of Gurth, to be conducted in safety to the  barbican, the road to which was now cleared of the enemy, and not yet  interrupted by the flames. This accomplished, the loyal Cedric hastened in  quest of his friend Athelstane, determined, at every risk to himself, to save  that last scion of Saxon royalty. But ere Cedric penetrated as far as the old  hall in which he had himself been a prisoner, the inventive genius of Wamba had  procured liberation for himself and his companion in adversity.          When the noise of the conflict announced that it was at the hottest, the Jester  began to shout, with the utmost power of his lungs, &ldquo;Saint George and the  dragon!&mdash;Bonny Saint George for merry England!&mdash;The castle is  won!&rdquo; And these sounds he rendered yet more fearful, by banging against  each other two or three pieces of rusty armour which lay scattered around the  hall.          A guard, which had been stationed in the outer, or anteroom, and whose spirits  were already in a state of alarm, took fright at Wamba&rsquo;s clamour, and,  leaving the door open behind them, ran to tell the Templar that foemen had  entered the old hall. Meantime the prisoners found no difficulty in making  their escape into the anteroom, and from thence into the court of the castle,  which was now the last scene of contest. Here sat the fierce Templar, mounted  on horseback, surrounded by several of the garrison both on horse and foot, who  had united their strength to that of this renowned leader, in order to secure  the last chance of safety and retreat which remained to them. The drawbridge  had been lowered by his orders, but the passage was beset; for the archers, who  had hitherto only annoyed the castle on that side by their missiles, no sooner  saw the flames breaking out, and the bridge lowered, than they thronged to the  entrance, as well to prevent the escape of the garrison, as to secure their own  share of booty ere the castle should be burnt down. On the other hand, a party  of the besiegers who had entered by the postern were now issuing out into the  court-yard, and attacking with fury the remnant of the defenders who were thus  assaulted on both sides at once.          Animated, however, by despair, and supported by the example of their  indomitable leader, the remaining soldiers of the castle fought with the utmost  valour; and, being well-armed, succeeded more than once in driving back the  assailants, though much inferior in numbers. Rebecca, placed on horseback  before one of the Templar&rsquo;s Saracen slaves, was in the midst of the  little party; and Bois-Guilbert, notwithstanding the confusion of the bloody  fray, showed every attention to her safety. Repeatedly he was by her side, and,  neglecting his own defence, held before her the fence of his triangular  steel-plated shield; and anon starting from his position by her, he cried his  war-cry, dashed forward, struck to earth the most forward of the assailants,  and was on the same instant once more at her bridle rein.          Athelstane, who, as the reader knows, was slothful, but not cowardly, beheld  the female form whom the Templar protected thus sedulously, and doubted not  that it was Rowena whom the knight was carrying off, in despite of all  resistance which could be offered.          &ldquo;By the soul of Saint Edward,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;I will rescue her  from yonder over-proud knight, and he shall die by my hand!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Think what you do!&rdquo; cried Wamba; &ldquo;hasty hand catches frog  for fish&mdash;by my bauble, yonder is none of my Lady Rowena&mdash;see but her  long dark locks!&mdash;Nay, an ye will not know black from white, ye may be  leader, but I will be no follower&mdash;no bones of mine shall be broken unless  I know for whom.&mdash;And you without armour too!&mdash;Bethink you, silk  bonnet never kept out steel blade.&mdash;Nay, then, if wilful will to water,  wilful must drench.&mdash;&lsquo;Deus vobiscum&rsquo;, most doughty  Athelstane!&rdquo;&mdash;he concluded, loosening the hold which he had hitherto  kept upon the Saxon&rsquo;s tunic.          To snatch a mace from the pavement, on which it lay beside one whose dying  grasp had just relinquished it&mdash;to rush on the Templar&rsquo;s band, and  to strike in quick succession to the right and left, levelling a warrior at  each blow, was, for Athelstane&rsquo;s great strength, now animated with  unusual fury, but the work of a single moment; he was soon within two yards of  Bois-Guilbert, whom he defied in his loudest tone.          &ldquo;Turn, false-hearted Templar! let go her whom thou art unworthy to  touch&mdash;turn, limb of a hand of murdering and hypocritical robbers!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Dog!&rdquo; said the Templar, grinding his teeth, &ldquo;I will teach  thee to blaspheme the holy Order of the Temple of Zion;&rdquo; and with these  words, half-wheeling his steed, he made a demi-courbette towards the Saxon, and  rising in the stirrups, so as to take full advantage of the descent of the  horse, he discharged a fearful blow upon the head of Athelstane.          Well said Wamba, that silken bonnet keeps out no steel blade. So trenchant was  the Templar&rsquo;s weapon, that it shore asunder, as it had been a willow  twig, the tough and plaited handle of the mace, which the ill-fated Saxon  reared to parry the blow, and, descending on his head, levelled him with the  earth.          &ldquo;&lsquo;Ha! Beau-seant!&rsquo;&rdquo; exclaimed Bois-Guilbert,  &ldquo;thus be it to the maligners of the Temple-knights!&rdquo; Taking  advantage of the dismay which was spread by the fall of Athelstane, and calling  aloud, &ldquo;Those who would save themselves, follow me!&rdquo; he pushed  across the drawbridge, dispersing the archers who would have intercepted them.  He was followed by his Saracens, and some five or six men-at-arms, who had  mounted their horses. The Templar&rsquo;s retreat was rendered perilous by the  numbers of arrows shot off at him and his party; but this did not prevent him  from galloping round to the barbican, of which, according to his previous plan,  he supposed it possible De Bracy might have been in possession.          &ldquo;De Bracy! De Bracy!&rdquo; he shouted, &ldquo;art thou there?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am here,&rdquo; replied De Bracy, &ldquo;but I am a prisoner.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Can I rescue thee?&rdquo; cried Bois-Guilbert.          &ldquo;No,&rdquo; replied De Bracy; &ldquo;I have rendered me, rescue or no  rescue. I will be true prisoner. Save thyself&mdash;there are hawks  abroad&mdash;put the seas betwixt you and England&mdash;I dare not say  more.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Well,&rdquo; answered the Templar, &ldquo;an thou wilt tarry there,  remember I have redeemed word and glove. Be the hawks where they will, methinks  the walls of the Preceptory of Templestowe will be cover sufficient, and  thither will I, like heron to her haunt.&rdquo;          Having thus spoken, he galloped off with his followers.          Those of the castle who had not gotten to horse, still continued to fight  desperately with the besiegers, after the departure of the Templar, but rather  in despair of quarter than that they entertained any hope of escape. The fire  was spreading rapidly through all parts of the castle, when Ulrica, who had  first kindled it, appeared on a turret, in the guise of one of the ancient  furies, yelling forth a war-song, such as was of yore raised on the field of  battle by the scalds of the yet heathen Saxons. Her long dishevelled grey hair  flew back from her uncovered head; the inebriating delight of gratified  vengeance contended in her eyes with the fire of insanity; and she brandished  the distaff which she held in her hand, as if she had been one of the Fatal  Sisters, who spin and abridge the thread of human life. Tradition has preserved  some wild strophes of the barbarous hymn which she chanted wildly amid that  scene of fire and of slaughter:&mdash;          1.   Whet the bright steel,   Sons of the White Dragon!   Kindle the torch,   Daughter of Hengist!   The steel glimmers not for the carving of the banquet,   It is hard, broad, and sharply pointed;   The torch goeth not to the bridal chamber,   It steams and glitters blue with sulphur.   Whet the steel, the raven croaks!   Light the torch, Zernebock is yelling!   Whet the steel, sons of the Dragon!   Kindle the torch, daughter of Hengist!      2.   The black cloud is low over the thane&rsquo;s castle   The eagle screams&mdash;he rides on its bosom.   Scream not, grey rider of the sable cloud,   Thy banquet is prepared!   The maidens of Valhalla look forth,   The race of Hengist will send them guests.   Shake your black tresses, maidens of Valhalla!   And strike your loud timbrels for joy!   Many a haughty step bends to your halls,   Many a helmed head.      3.   Dark sits the evening upon the thanes castle,   The black clouds gather round;   Soon shall they be red as the blood of the valiant!   The destroyer of forests shall shake his red crest against   them.   He, the bright consumer of palaces,   Broad waves he his blazing banner,   Red, wide and dusky,   Over the strife of the valiant:   His joy is in the clashing swords and broken bucklers;   He loves to lick the hissing blood as it bursts warm from the   wound!      4.   All must perish!   The sword cleaveth the helmet;   The strong armour is pierced by the lance;   Fire devoureth the dwelling of princes,   Engines break down the fences of the battle.   All must perish!   The race of Hengist is gone&mdash;   The name of Horsa is no more!   Shrink not then from your doom, sons of the sword!   Let your blades drink blood like wine;   Feast ye in the banquet of slaughter,   By the light of the blazing halls!   Strong be your swords while your blood is warm,   And spare neither for pity nor fear,   For vengeance hath but an hour;   Strong hate itself shall expire   I also must perish!  39           The towering flames had now surmounted every obstruction, and rose to the  evening skies one huge and burning beacon, seen far and wide through the  adjacent country. Tower after tower crashed down, with blazing roof and rafter;  and the combatants were driven from the court-yard. The vanquished, of whom  very few remained, scattered and escaped into the neighbouring wood. The  victors, assembling in large bands, gazed with wonder, not unmixed with fear,  upon the flames, in which their own ranks and arms glanced dusky red. The  maniac figure of the Saxon Ulrica was for a long time visible on the lofty  stand she had chosen, tossing her arms abroad with wild exultation, as if she  reined empress of the conflagration which she had raised. At length, with a  terrific crash, the whole turret gave way, and she perished in the flames which  had consumed her tyrant. An awful pause of horror silenced each murmur of the  armed spectators, who, for the space of several minutes, stirred not a finger,  save to sign the cross. The voice of Locksley was then heard, &ldquo;Shout,  yeomen!&mdash;the den of tyrants is no more! Let each bring his spoil to our  chosen place of rendezvous at the Trysting-tree in the Harthill-walk; for there  at break of day will we make just partition among our own bands, together with  our worthy allies in this great deed of vengeance.&rdquo;                     CHAPTER XXXII.        Trust me each state must have its policies:   Kingdoms have edicts, cities have their charters;   Even the wild outlaw, in his forest-walk,   Keeps yet some touch of civil discipline;   For not since Adam wore his verdant apron,   Hath man with man in social union dwelt,   But laws were made to draw that union closer.          O LD  P LAY           The daylight had dawned upon the glades of the oak forest. The green boughs  glittered with all their pearls of dew. The hind led her fawn from the covert  of high fern to the more open walks of the greenwood, and no huntsman was there  to watch or intercept the stately hart, as he paced at the head of the  antler&rsquo;d herd.          The outlaws were all assembled around the Trysting-tree in the Harthill-walk,  where they had spent the night in refreshing themselves after the fatigues of  the siege, some with wine, some with slumber, many with hearing and recounting  the events of the day, and computing the heaps of plunder which their success  had placed at the disposal of their Chief.          The spoils were indeed very large; for, notwithstanding that much was consumed,  a great deal of plate, rich armour, and splendid clothing, had been secured by  the exertions of the dauntless outlaws, who could be appalled by no danger when  such rewards were in view. Yet so strict were the laws of their society, that  no one ventured to appropriate any part of the booty, which was brought into  one common mass, to be at the disposal of their leader.          The place of rendezvous was an aged oak; not however the same to which Locksley  had conducted Gurth and Wamba in the earlier part of the story, but one which  was the centre of a silvan amphitheatre, within half a mile of the demolished  castle of Torquilstone. Here Locksley assumed his seat&mdash;a throne of turf  erected under the twisted branches of the huge oak, and the silvan followers  were gathered around him. He assigned to the Black Knight a seat at his right  hand, and to Cedric a place upon his left.          &ldquo;Pardon my freedom, noble sirs,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;but in these  glades I am monarch&mdash;they are my kingdom; and these my wild subjects would  reck but little of my power, were I, within my own dominions, to yield place to  mortal man.&mdash;Now, sirs, who hath seen our chaplain? where is our curtal  Friar? A mass amongst Christian men best begins a busy morning.&rdquo;&mdash;No  one had seen the Clerk of Copmanhurst. &ldquo;Over gods forbode!&rdquo; said  the outlaw chief, &ldquo;I trust the jolly priest hath but abidden by the  wine-pot a thought too late. Who saw him since the castle was  ta&rsquo;en?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I,&rdquo; quoth the Miller, &ldquo;marked him busy about the door of a  cellar, swearing by each saint in the calendar he would taste the smack of  Front-de-Bœuf&rsquo;s Gascoigne wine.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Now, the saints, as many as there be of them,&rdquo; said the Captain,  &ldquo;forefend, lest he has drunk too deep of the wine-butts, and perished by  the fall of the castle!&mdash;Away, Miller!&mdash;take with you enow of men,  seek the place where you last saw him&mdash;throw water from the moat on the  scorching ruins&mdash;I will have them removed stone by stone ere I lose my  curtal Friar.&rdquo;          The numbers who hastened to execute this duty, considering that an interesting  division of spoil was about to take place, showed how much the troop had at  heart the safety of their spiritual father.          &ldquo;Meanwhile, let us proceed,&rdquo; said Locksley; &ldquo;for when this  bold deed shall be sounded abroad, the bands of De Bracy, of Malvoisin, and  other allies of Front-de-Bœuf, will be in motion against us, and it were well  for our safety that we retreat from the vicinity.&mdash;Noble Cedric,&rdquo; he  said, turning to the Saxon, &ldquo;that spoil is divided into two portions; do  thou make choice of that which best suits thee, to recompense thy people who  were partakers with us in this adventure.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Good yeoman,&rdquo; said Cedric, &ldquo;my heart is oppressed with  sadness. The noble Athelstane of Coningsburgh is no more&mdash;the last sprout  of the sainted Confessor! Hopes have perished with him which can never  return!&mdash;A sparkle hath been quenched by his blood, which no human breath  can again rekindle! My people, save the few who are now with me, do but tarry  my presence to transport his honoured remains to their last mansion. The Lady  Rowena is desirous to return to Rotherwood, and must be escorted by a  sufficient force. I should, therefore, ere now, have left this place; and I  waited&mdash;not to share the booty, for, so help me God and Saint Withold! as  neither I nor any of mine will touch the value of a liard,&mdash;I waited but  to render my thanks to thee and to thy bold yeomen, for the life and honour ye  have saved.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, but,&rdquo; said the chief Outlaw, &ldquo;we did but half the work  at most&mdash;take of the spoil what may reward your own neighbours and  followers.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am rich enough to reward them from mine own wealth,&rdquo; answered  Cedric.          &ldquo;And some,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;have been wise enough to reward  themselves; they do not march off empty-handed altogether. We do not all wear  motley.&rdquo;          &ldquo;They are welcome,&rdquo; said Locksley; &ldquo;our laws bind none but  ourselves.&rdquo;          &ldquo;But, thou, my poor knave,&rdquo; said Cedric, turning about and  embracing his Jester, &ldquo;how shall I reward thee, who feared not to give  thy body to chains and death instead of mine!&mdash;All forsook me, when the  poor fool was faithful!&rdquo;          A tear stood in the eye of the rough Thane as he spoke&mdash;a mark of feeling  which even the death of Athelstane had not extracted; but there was something  in the half-instinctive attachment of his clown, that waked his nature more  keenly than even grief itself.          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; said the Jester, extricating himself from master&rsquo;s  caress, &ldquo;if you pay my service with the water of your eye, the Jester  must weep for company, and then what becomes of his vocation?&mdash;But, uncle,  if you would indeed pleasure me, I pray you to pardon my playfellow Gurth, who  stole a week from your service to bestow it on your son.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Pardon him!&rdquo; exclaimed Cedric; &ldquo;I will both pardon and  reward him.&mdash;Kneel down, Gurth.&rdquo;&mdash;The swineherd was in an  instant at his master&rsquo;s feet&mdash;&ldquo;THEOW and ESNE   40   art thou no longer,&rdquo; said  Cedric touching him with a wand; &ldquo;FOLKFREE and SACLESS   41   art thou in town and from town, in  the forest as in the field. A hide of land I give to thee in my steads of  Walbrugham, from me and mine to thee and thine aye and for ever; and  God&rsquo;s malison on his head who this gainsays!&rdquo;          No longer a serf, but a freeman and a landholder, Gurth sprung upon his feet,  and twice bounded aloft to almost his own height from the ground. &ldquo;A  smith and a file,&rdquo; he cried, &ldquo;to do away the collar from the neck  of a freeman!&mdash;Noble master! doubled is my strength by your gift, and  doubly will I fight for you!&mdash;There is a free spirit in my breast&mdash;I  am a man changed to myself and all around.&mdash;Ha, Fangs!&rdquo; he  continued,&mdash;for that faithful cur, seeing his master thus transported,  began to jump upon him, to express his sympathy,&mdash;&ldquo;knowest thou thy  master still?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;Fangs and I still know thee, Gurth, though  we must needs abide by the collar; it is only thou art likely to forget both us  and thyself.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I shall forget myself indeed ere I forget thee, true comrade,&rdquo;  said Gurth; &ldquo;and were freedom fit for thee, Wamba, the master would not  let thee want it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;never think I envy thee, brother Gurth;  the serf sits by the hall-fire when the freeman must forth to the field of  battle&mdash;And what saith Oldhelm of Malmsbury&mdash;Better a fool at a feast  than a wise man at a fray.&rdquo;          The tramp of horses was now heard, and the Lady Rowena appeared, surrounded by  several riders, and a much stronger party of footmen, who joyfully shook their  pikes and clashed their brown-bills for joy of her freedom. She herself, richly  attired, and mounted on a dark chestnut palfrey, had recovered all the dignity  of her manner, and only an unwonted degree of paleness showed the sufferings  she had undergone. Her lovely brow, though sorrowful, bore on it a cast of  reviving hope for the future, as well as of grateful thankfulness for the past  deliverance&mdash;She knew that Ivanhoe was safe, and she knew that Athelstane  was dead. The former assurance filled her with the most sincere delight; and if  she did not absolutely rejoice at the latter, she might be pardoned for feeling  the full advantage of being freed from further persecution on the only subject  in which she had ever been contradicted by her guardian Cedric.          As Rowena bent her steed towards Locksley&rsquo;s seat, that bold yeoman, with  all his followers, rose to receive her, as if by a general instinct of  courtesy. The blood rose to her cheeks, as, courteously waving her hand, and  bending so low that her beautiful and loose tresses were for an instant mixed  with the flowing mane of her palfrey, she expressed in few but apt words her  obligations and her gratitude to Locksley and her other  deliverers.&mdash;&ldquo;God bless you, brave men,&rdquo; she concluded,  &ldquo;God and Our Lady bless you and requite you for gallantly perilling  yourselves in the cause of the oppressed!&mdash;If any of you should hunger,  remember Rowena has food&mdash;if you should thirst, she has many a butt of  wine and brown ale&mdash;and if the Normans drive ye from these walks, Rowena  has forests of her own, where her gallant deliverers may range at full freedom,  and never ranger ask whose arrow hath struck down the deer.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thanks, gentle lady,&rdquo; said Locksley; &ldquo;thanks from my company  and myself. But, to have saved you requites itself. We who walk the greenwood  do many a wild deed, and the Lady Rowena&rsquo;s deliverance may be received as  an atonement.&rdquo;          Again bowing from her palfrey, Rowena turned to depart; but pausing a moment,  while Cedric, who was to attend her, was also taking his leave, she found  herself unexpectedly close by the prisoner De Bracy. He stood under a tree in  deep meditation, his arms crossed upon his breast, and Rowena was in hopes she  might pass him unobserved. He looked up, however, and, when aware of her  presence, a deep flush of shame suffused his handsome countenance. He stood a  moment most irresolute; then, stepping forward, took her palfrey by the rein,  and bent his knee before her.          &ldquo;Will the Lady Rowena deign to cast an eye&mdash;on a captive  knight&mdash;on a dishonoured soldier?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Sir Knight,&rdquo; answered Rowena, &ldquo;in enterprises such as yours,  the real dishonour lies not in failure, but in success.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Conquest, lady, should soften the heart,&rdquo; answered De Bracy;  &ldquo;let me but know that the Lady Rowena forgives the violence occasioned by  an ill-fated passion, and she shall soon learn that De Bracy knows how to serve  her in nobler ways.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I forgive you, Sir Knight,&rdquo; said Rowena, &ldquo;as a  Christian.&rdquo;          &ldquo;That means,&rdquo; said Wamba, &ldquo;that she does not forgive him at  all.&rdquo;          &ldquo;But I can never forgive the misery and desolation your madness has  occasioned,&rdquo; continued Rowena.          &ldquo;Unloose your hold on the lady&rsquo;s rein,&rdquo; said Cedric, coming  up. &ldquo;By the bright sun above us, but it were shame, I would pin thee to  the earth with my javelin&mdash;but be well assured, thou shalt smart, Maurice  de Bracy, for thy share in this foul deed.&rdquo;          &ldquo;He threatens safely who threatens a prisoner,&rdquo; said De Bracy;  &ldquo;but when had a Saxon any touch of courtesy?&rdquo;          Then retiring two steps backward, he permitted the lady to move on.          Cedric, ere they departed, expressed his peculiar gratitude to the Black  Champion, and earnestly entreated him to accompany him to Rotherwood.          &ldquo;I know,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;that ye errant knights desire to carry  your fortunes on the point of your lance, and reck not of land or goods; but  war is a changeful mistress, and a home is sometimes desirable even to the  champion whose trade is wandering. Thou hast earned one in the halls of  Rotherwood, noble knight. Cedric has wealth enough to repair the injuries of  fortune, and all he has is his deliverer&rsquo;s&mdash;Come, therefore, to  Rotherwood, not as a guest, but as a son or brother.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Cedric has already made me rich,&rdquo; said the Knight,&mdash;&ldquo;he  has taught me the value of Saxon virtue. To Rotherwood will I come, brave  Saxon, and that speedily; but, as now, pressing matters of moment detain me  from your halls. Peradventure when I come hither, I will ask such a boon as  will put even thy generosity to the test.&rdquo;          &ldquo;It is granted ere spoken out,&rdquo; said Cedric, striking his ready  hand into the gauntleted palm of the Black Knight,&mdash;&ldquo;it is granted  already, were it to affect half my fortune.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Gage not thy promise so lightly,&rdquo; said the Knight of the  Fetterlock; &ldquo;yet well I hope to gain the boon I shall ask. Meanwhile,  adieu.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I have but to say,&rdquo; added the Saxon, &ldquo;that, during the  funeral rites of the noble Athelstane, I shall be an inhabitant of the halls of  his castle of Coningsburgh&mdash;They will be open to all who choose to partake  of the funeral banqueting; and, I speak in name of the noble Edith, mother of  the fallen prince, they will never be shut against him who laboured so bravely,  though unsuccessfully, to save Athelstane from Norman chains and Norman  steel.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay, ay,&rdquo; said Wamba, who had resumed his attendance on his master,  &ldquo;rare feeding there will be&mdash;pity that the noble Athelstane cannot  banquet at his own funeral.&mdash;But he,&rdquo; continued the Jester, lifting  up his eyes gravely, &ldquo;is supping in Paradise, and doubtless does honour  to the cheer.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Peace, and move on,&rdquo; said Cedric, his anger at this untimely jest  being checked by the recollection of Wamba&rsquo;s recent services. Rowena  waved a graceful adieu to him of the Fetterlock&mdash;the Saxon bade God speed  him, and on they moved through a wide glade of the forest.          They had scarce departed, ere a sudden procession moved from under the  greenwood branches, swept slowly round the silvan amphitheatre, and took the  same direction with Rowena and her followers. The priests of a neighbouring  convent, in expectation of the ample donation, or &ldquo;soul-scat&rdquo;,  which Cedric had propined, attended upon the car in which the body of  Athelstane was laid, and sang hymns as it was sadly and slowly borne on the  shoulders of his vassals to his castle of Coningsburgh, to be there deposited  in the grave of Hengist, from whom the deceased derived his long descent. Many  of his vassals had assembled at the news of his death, and followed the bier  with all the external marks, at least, of dejection and sorrow. Again the  outlaws arose, and paid the same rude and spontaneous homage to death, which  they had so lately rendered to beauty&mdash;the slow chant and mournful step of  the priests brought back to their remembrance such of their comrades as had  fallen in the yesterday&rsquo;s array. But such recollections dwell not long  with those who lead a life of danger and enterprise, and ere the sound of the  death-hymn had died on the wind, the outlaws were again busied in the  distribution of their spoil.          &ldquo;Valiant knight,&rdquo; said Locksley to the Black Champion,  &ldquo;without whose good heart and mighty arm our enterprise must altogether  have failed, will it please you to take from that mass of spoil whatever may  best serve to pleasure you, and to remind you of this my Trysting-tree?&rdquo;          &ldquo;I accept the offer,&rdquo; said the Knight, &ldquo;as frankly as it is  given; and I ask permission to dispose of Sir Maurice de Bracy at my own  pleasure.&rdquo;          &ldquo;He is thine already,&rdquo; said Locksley, &ldquo;and well for him! else  the tyrant had graced the highest bough of this oak, with as many of his  Free-Companions as we could gather, hanging thick as acorns around  him.&mdash;But he is thy prisoner, and he is safe, though he had slain my  father.&rdquo;          &ldquo;De Bracy,&rdquo; said the Knight, &ldquo;thou art free&mdash;depart. He  whose prisoner thou art scorns to take mean revenge for what is past. But  beware of the future, lest a worse thing befall thee.&mdash;Maurice de Bracy, I  say BEWARE!&rdquo;          De Bracy bowed low and in silence, and was about to withdraw, when the yeomen  burst at once into a shout of execration and derision. The proud knight  instantly stopped, turned back, folded his arms, drew up his form to its full  height, and exclaimed, &ldquo;Peace, ye yelping curs! who open upon a cry which  ye followed not when the stag was at bay&mdash;De Bracy scorns your censure as  he would disdain your applause. To your brakes and caves, ye outlawed thieves!  and be silent when aught knightly or noble is but spoken within a league of  your fox-earths.&rdquo;          This ill-timed defiance might have procured for De Bracy a volley of arrows,  but for the hasty and imperative interference of the outlaw Chief. Meanwhile  the knight caught a horse by the rein, for several which had been taken in the  stables of Front-de-Bœuf stood accoutred around, and were a valuable part of  the booty. He threw himself upon the saddle, and galloped off through the wood.          When the bustle occasioned by this incident was somewhat composed, the chief  Outlaw took from his neck the rich horn and baldric which he had recently  gained at the strife of archery near Ashby.          &ldquo;Noble knight.&rdquo; he said to him of the Fetterlock, &ldquo;if you  disdain not to grace by your acceptance a bugle which an English yeoman has  once worn, this I will pray you to keep as a memorial of your gallant  bearing&mdash;and if ye have aught to do, and, as happeneth oft to a gallant  knight, ye chance to be hard bested in any forest between Trent and Tees, wind  three mots   42   upon the horn thus,  &lsquo;Wa-sa-hoa!&rsquo; and it may well chance ye shall find helpers and  rescue.&rdquo;          He then gave breath to the bugle, and winded once and again the call which he  described, until the knight had caught the notes.          &ldquo;Gramercy for the gift, bold yeoman,&rdquo; said the Knight; &ldquo;and  better help than thine and thy rangers would I never seek, were it at my utmost  need.&rdquo; And then in his turn he winded the call till all the greenwood  rang.          &ldquo;Well blown and clearly,&rdquo; said the yeoman; &ldquo;beshrew me an  thou knowest not as much of woodcraft as of war!&mdash;thou hast been a striker  of deer in thy day, I warrant.&mdash;Comrades, mark these three mots&mdash;it  is the call of the Knight of the Fetterlock; and he who hears it, and hastens  not to serve him at his need, I will have him scourged out of our band with his  own bowstring.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Long live our leader!&rdquo; shouted the yeomen, &ldquo;and long live  the Black Knight of the Fetterlock!&mdash;May he soon use our service, to prove  how readily it will be paid.&rdquo;          Locksley now proceeded to the distribution of the spoil, which he performed  with the most laudable impartiality. A tenth part of the whole was set apart  for the church, and for pious uses; a portion was next allotted to a sort of  public treasury; a part was assigned to the widows and children of those who  had fallen, or to be expended in masses for the souls of such as had left no  surviving family. The rest was divided amongst the outlaws, according to their  rank and merit, and the judgment of the Chief, on all such doubtful questions  as occurred, was delivered with great shrewdness, and received with absolute  submission. The Black Knight was not a little surprised to find that men, in a  state so lawless, were nevertheless among themselves so regularly and equitably  governed, and all that he observed added to his opinion of the justice and  judgment of their leader.          When each had taken his own proportion of the booty, and while the treasurer,  accompanied by four tall yeomen, was transporting that belonging to the state  to some place of concealment or of security, the portion devoted to the church  still remained unappropriated.          &ldquo;I would,&rdquo; said the leader, &ldquo;we could hear tidings of our  joyous chaplain&mdash;he was never wont to be absent when meat was to be  blessed, or spoil to be parted; and it is his duty to take care of these the  tithes of our successful enterprise. It may be the office has helped to cover  some of his canonical irregularities. Also, I have a holy brother of his a  prisoner at no great distance, and I would fain have the Friar to help me to  deal with him in due sort&mdash;I greatly misdoubt the safety of the bluff  priest.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I were right sorry for that,&rdquo; said the Knight of the Fetterlock,  &ldquo;for I stand indebted to him for the joyous hospitality of a merry night  in his cell. Let us to the ruins of the castle; it may be we shall there learn  some tidings of him.&rdquo;          While they thus spoke, a loud shout among the yeomen announced the arrival of  him for whom they feared, as they learned from the stentorian voice of the  Friar himself, long before they saw his burly person.          &ldquo;Make room, my merry-men!&rdquo; he exclaimed; &ldquo;room for your godly  father and his prisoner&mdash;Cry welcome once more.&mdash;I come, noble  leader, like an eagle with my prey in my clutch.&rdquo;&mdash;And making his  way through the ring, amidst the laughter of all around, he appeared in  majestic triumph, his huge partisan in one hand, and in the other a halter, one  end of which was fastened to the neck of the unfortunate Isaac of York, who,  bent down by sorrow and terror, was dragged on by the victorious priest, who  shouted aloud, &ldquo;Where is Allan-a-Dale, to chronicle me in a ballad, or if  it were but a lay?&mdash;By Saint Hermangild, the jingling crowder is ever out  of the way where there is an apt theme for exalting valour!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Curtal Priest,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;thou hast been at a wet  mass this morning, as early as it is. In the name of Saint Nicholas, whom hast  thou got here?&rdquo;          &ldquo;A captive to my sword and to my lance, noble Captain,&rdquo; replied the  Clerk of Copmanhurst; &ldquo;to my bow and to my halberd, I should rather say;  and yet I have redeemed him by my divinity from a worse captivity. Speak,  Jew&mdash;have I not ransomed thee from Sathanas?&mdash;have I not taught thee  thy &lsquo;credo&rsquo;, thy &lsquo;pater&rsquo;, and thine &lsquo;Ave  Maria&rsquo;?&mdash;Did I not spend the whole night in drinking to thee, and in  expounding of mysteries?&rdquo;          &ldquo;For the love of God!&rdquo; ejaculated the poor Jew, &ldquo;will no one  take me out of the keeping of this mad&mdash;I mean this holy man?&rdquo;          &ldquo;How&rsquo;s this, Jew?&rdquo; said the Friar, with a menacing aspect;  &ldquo;dost thou recant, Jew?&mdash;Bethink thee, if thou dost relapse into  thine infidelity, though thou are not so tender as a suckling pig&mdash;I would  I had one to break my fast upon&mdash;thou art not too tough to be roasted! Be  conformable, Isaac, and repeat the words after me. &lsquo;Ave  Maria&rsquo;!&mdash;&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, we will have no profanation, mad Priest,&rdquo; said Locksley;  &ldquo;let us rather hear where you found this prisoner of thine.&rdquo;          &ldquo;By Saint Dunstan,&rdquo; said the Friar, &ldquo;I found him where I  sought for better ware! I did step into the cellarage to see what might be  rescued there; for though a cup of burnt wine, with spice, be an  evening&rsquo;s drought for an emperor, it were waste, methought, to let so  much good liquor be mulled at once; and I had caught up one runlet of sack, and  was coming to call more aid among these lazy knaves, who are ever to seek when  a good deed is to be done, when I was avised of a strong door&mdash;Aha!  thought I, here is the choicest juice of all in this secret crypt; and the  knave butler, being disturbed in his vocation, hath left the key in the  door&mdash;In therefore I went, and found just nought besides a commodity of  rusted chains and this dog of a Jew, who presently rendered himself my  prisoner, rescue or no rescue. I did but refresh myself after the fatigue of  the action, with the unbeliever, with one humming cup of sack, and was  proceeding to lead forth my captive, when, crash after crash, as with wild  thunder-dint and levin-fire, down toppled the masonry of an outer tower, (marry  beshrew their hands that built it not the firmer!) and blocked up the passage.  The roar of one falling tower followed another&mdash;I gave up thought of life;  and deeming it a dishonour to one of my profession to pass out of this world in  company with a Jew, I heaved up my halberd to beat his brains out; but I took  pity on his grey hairs, and judged it better to lay down the partisan, and take  up my spiritual weapon for his conversion. And truly, by the blessing of Saint  Dunstan, the seed has been sown in good soil; only that, with speaking to him  of mysteries through the whole night, and being in a manner fasting, (for the  few droughts of sack which I sharpened my wits with were not worth marking,) my  head is well-nigh dizzied, I trow.&mdash;But I was clean  exhausted.&mdash;Gilbert and Wibbald know in what state they found  me&mdash;quite and clean exhausted.&rdquo;          &ldquo;We can bear witness,&rdquo; said Gilbert; &ldquo;for when we had cleared  away the ruin, and by Saint Dunstan&rsquo;s help lighted upon the dungeon  stair, we found the runlet of sack half empty, the Jew half dead, and the Friar  more than half&mdash;exhausted, as he calls it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ye be knaves! ye lie!&rdquo; retorted the offended Friar; &ldquo;it was  you and your gormandizing companions that drank up the sack, and called it your  morning draught&mdash;I am a pagan, an I kept it not for the Captain&rsquo;s  own throat. But what recks it? The Jew is converted, and understands all I have  told him, very nearly, if not altogether, as well as myself.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Jew,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;is this true? hast thou renounced  thine unbelief?&rdquo;          &ldquo;May I so find mercy in your eyes,&rdquo; said the Jew, &ldquo;as I know  not one word which the reverend prelate spake to me all this fearful night.  Alas! I was so distraught with agony, and fear, and grief, that had our holy  father Abraham come to preach to me, he had found but a deaf listener.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou liest, Jew, and thou knowest thou dost.&rdquo; said the Friar;  &ldquo;I will remind thee of but one word of our conference&mdash;thou didst  promise to give all thy substance to our holy Order.&rdquo;          &ldquo;So help me the Promise, fair sirs,&rdquo; said Isaac, even more alarmed  than before, &ldquo;as no such sounds ever crossed my lips! Alas! I am an aged  beggar&rsquo;d man&mdash;I fear me a childless&mdash;have ruth on me, and let  me go!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; said the Friar, &ldquo;if thou dost retract vows made in  favour of holy Church, thou must do penance.&rdquo;          Accordingly, he raised his halberd, and would have laid the staff of it lustily  on the Jew&rsquo;s shoulders, had not the Black Knight stopped the blow, and  thereby transferred the Holy Clerk&rsquo;s resentment to himself.          &ldquo;By Saint Thomas of Kent,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;an I buckle to my gear,  I will teach thee, sir lazy lover, to mell with thine own matters, maugre thine  iron case there!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, be not wroth with me,&rdquo; said the Knight; &ldquo;thou knowest I  am thy sworn friend and comrade.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I know no such thing,&rdquo; answered the Friar; &ldquo;and defy thee  for a meddling coxcomb!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, but,&rdquo; said the Knight, who seemed to take a pleasure in  provoking his quondam host, &ldquo;hast thou forgotten how, that for my sake  (for I say nothing of the temptation of the flagon and the pasty) thou didst  break thy vow of fast and vigil?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Truly, friend,&rdquo; said the Friar, clenching his huge fist, &ldquo;I  will bestow a buffet on thee.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I accept of no such presents,&rdquo; said the Knight; &ldquo;I am  content to take thy cuff   421   as a loan, but I will repay thee  with usury as deep as ever thy prisoner there exacted in his traffic.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I will prove that presently,&rdquo; said the Friar.          &ldquo;Hola!&rdquo; cried the Captain, &ldquo;what art thou after, mad Friar?  brawling beneath our Trysting-tree?&rdquo;          &ldquo;No brawling,&rdquo; said the Knight, &ldquo;it is but a friendly  interchange of courtesy.&mdash;Friar, strike an thou darest&mdash;I will stand  thy blow, if thou wilt stand mine.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou hast the advantage with that iron pot on thy head,&rdquo; said the  churchman; &ldquo;but have at thee&mdash;Down thou goest, an thou wert Goliath  of Gath in his brazen helmet.&rdquo;          The Friar bared his brawny arm up to the elbow, and putting his full strength  to the blow, gave the Knight a buffet that might have felled an ox. But his  adversary stood firm as a rock. A loud shout was uttered by all the yeomen  around; for the Clerk&rsquo;s cuff was proverbial amongst them, and there were  few who, in jest or earnest, had not had the occasion to know its vigour.          &ldquo;Now, Priest,&rdquo; said, the Knight, pulling off his gauntlet,  &ldquo;if I had vantage on my head, I will have none on my hand&mdash;stand  fast as a true man.&rdquo;          &ldquo;&lsquo;Genam meam dedi vapulatori&rsquo;&mdash;I have given my cheek to  the smiter,&rdquo; said the Priest; &ldquo;an thou canst stir me from the spot,  fellow, I will freely bestow on thee the Jew&rsquo;s ransom.&rdquo;          So spoke the burly Priest, assuming, on his part, high defiance. But who may  resist his fate? The buffet of the Knight was given with such strength and  good-will, that the Friar rolled head over heels upon the plain, to the great  amazement of all the spectators. But he arose neither angry nor crestfallen.          &ldquo;Brother,&rdquo; said he to the Knight, &ldquo;thou shouldst have used  thy strength with more discretion. I had mumbled but a lame mass an thou hadst  broken my jaw, for the piper plays ill that wants the nether chops.  Nevertheless, there is my hand, in friendly witness, that I will exchange no  more cuffs with thee, having been a loser by the barter. End now all  unkindness. Let us put the Jew to ransom, since the leopard will not change his  spots, and a Jew he will continue to be.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The Priest,&rdquo; said Clement, &ldquo;is not half so confident of the  Jew&rsquo;s conversion, since he received that buffet on the ear.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Go to, knave, what pratest thou of conversions?&mdash;what, is there no  respect?&mdash;all masters and no men?&mdash;I tell thee, fellow, I was  somewhat totty when I received the good knight&rsquo;s blow, or I had kept my  ground under it. But an thou gibest more of it, thou shalt learn I can give as  well as take.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Peace all!&rdquo; said the Captain. &ldquo;And thou, Jew, think of thy  ransom; thou needest not to be told that thy race are held to be accursed in  all Christian communities, and trust me that we cannot endure thy presence  among us. Think, therefore, of an offer, while I examine a prisoner of another  cast.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Were many of Front-de-Bœuf&rsquo;s men taken?&rdquo; demanded the Black  Knight.          &ldquo;None of note enough to be put to ransom,&rdquo; answered the Captain;  &ldquo;a set of hilding fellows there were, whom we dismissed to find them a  new master&mdash;enough had been done for revenge and profit; the bunch of them  were not worth a cardecu. The prisoner I speak of is better booty&mdash;a jolly  monk riding to visit his leman, an I may judge by his horse-gear and wearing  apparel.&mdash;Here cometh the worthy prelate, as pert as a pyet.&rdquo; And,  between two yeomen, was brought before the silvan throne of the outlaw Chief,  our old friend, Prior Aymer of Jorvaulx.                     CHAPTER XXXIII        &mdash;-Flower of warriors,   How is&rsquo;t with Titus Lartius?   MARCIUS.&mdash;As with a man busied about decrees,   Condemning some to death and some to exile,   Ransoming him or pitying, threatening the other.          C ORIOLANUS           The captive Abbot&rsquo;s features and manners exhibited a whimsical mixture of  offended pride, and deranged foppery and bodily terror.          &ldquo;Why, how now, my masters?&rdquo; said he, with a voice in which all  three emotions were blended. &ldquo;What order is this among ye? Be ye Turks or  Christians, that handle a churchman?&mdash;Know ye what it is, &lsquo;manus  imponere in servos Domini&rsquo;? Ye have plundered my mails&mdash;torn my cope  of curious cut lace, which might have served a cardinal!&mdash;Another in my  place would have been at his &lsquo;excommunicabo vos&rsquo;; but I am  placible, and if ye order forth my palfreys, release my brethren, and restore  my mails, tell down with all speed an hundred crowns to be expended in masses  at the high altar of Jorvaulx Abbey, and make your vow to eat no venison until  next Pentecost, it may be you shall hear little more of this mad frolic.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Holy Father,&rdquo; said the chief Outlaw, &ldquo;it grieves me to think  that you have met with such usage from any of my followers, as calls for your  fatherly reprehension.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Usage!&rdquo; echoed the priest, encouraged by the mild tone of the  silvan leader; &ldquo;it were usage fit for no hound of good race&mdash;much  less for a Christian&mdash;far less for a priest&mdash;and least of all for the  Prior of the holy community of Jorvaulx. Here is a profane and drunken  minstrel, called Allan-a-Dale&mdash;&lsquo;nebulo quidam&rsquo;&mdash;who has  menaced me with corporal punishment&mdash;nay, with death itself, an I pay not  down four hundred crowns of ransom, to the boot of all the treasure he hath  already robbed me of&mdash;gold chains and gymmal rings to an unknown value;  besides what is broken and spoiled among their rude hands, such as my  pouncer-box and silver crisping-tongs.&rdquo;          &ldquo;It is impossible that Allan-a-Dale can have thus treated a man of your  reverend bearing,&rdquo; replied the Captain.          &ldquo;It is true as the gospel of Saint Nicodemus,&rdquo; said the Prior;  &ldquo;he swore, with many a cruel north-country oath, that he would hang me up  on the highest tree in the greenwood.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Did he so in very deed? Nay, then, reverend father, I think you had  better comply with his demands&mdash;for Allan-a-Dale is the very man to abide  by his word when he has so pledged it.&rdquo;   43            &ldquo;You do but jest with me,&rdquo; said the astounded Prior, with a forced  laugh; &ldquo;and I love a good jest with all my heart. But, ha! ha! ha! when  the mirth has lasted the livelong night, it is time to be grave in the  morning.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And I am as grave as a father confessor,&rdquo; replied the Outlaw;  &ldquo;you must pay a round ransom, Sir Prior, or your convent is likely to be  called to a new election; for your place will know you no more.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Are ye Christians,&rdquo; said the Prior, &ldquo;and hold this language  to a churchman?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Christians! ay, marry are we, and have divinity among us to boot,&rdquo;  answered the Outlaw. &ldquo;Let our buxom chaplain stand forth, and expound to  this reverend father the texts which concern this matter.&rdquo;          The Friar, half-drunk, half-sober, had huddled a friar&rsquo;s frock over his  green cassock, and now summoning together whatever scraps of learning he had  acquired by rote in former days, &ldquo;Holy father,&rdquo; said he,  &ldquo;&lsquo;Deus faciat salvam benignitatem vestram&rsquo;&mdash;You are  welcome to the greenwood.&rdquo;          &ldquo;What profane mummery is this?&rdquo; said the Prior. &ldquo;Friend, if  thou be&rsquo;st indeed of the church, it were a better deed to show me how I  may escape from these men&rsquo;s hands, than to stand ducking and grinning  here like a morris-dancer.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Truly, reverend father,&rdquo; said the Friar, &ldquo;I know but one  mode in which thou mayst escape. This is Saint Andrew&rsquo;s day with us, we  are taking our tithes.&rdquo;          &ldquo;But not of the church, then, I trust, my good brother?&rdquo; said the  Prior.          &ldquo;Of church and lay,&rdquo; said the Friar; &ldquo;and therefore, Sir  Prior &lsquo;facite vobis amicos de Mammone iniquitatis&rsquo;&mdash;make  yourselves friends of the Mammon of unrighteousness, for no other friendship is  like to serve your turn.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I love a jolly woodsman at heart,&rdquo; said the Prior, softening his  tone; &ldquo;come, ye must not deal too hard with me&mdash;I can well of  woodcraft, and can wind a horn clear and lustily, and hollo till every oak  rings again&mdash;Come, ye must not deal too hard with me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Give him a horn,&rdquo; said the Outlaw; &ldquo;we will prove the skill  he boasts of.&rdquo;          The Prior Aymer winded a blast accordingly. The Captain shook his head.          &ldquo;Sir Prior,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;thou blowest a merry note, but it may  not ransom thee&mdash;we cannot afford, as the legend on a good knight&rsquo;s  shield hath it, to set thee free for a blast. Moreover, I have found  thee&mdash;thou art one of those, who, with new French graces and Tra-li-ras,  disturb the ancient English bugle notes.&mdash;Prior, that last flourish on the  recheat hath added fifty crowns to thy ransom, for corrupting the true old  manly blasts of venerie.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Well, friend,&rdquo; said the Abbot, peevishly, &ldquo;thou art ill to  please with thy woodcraft. I pray thee be more conformable in this matter of my  ransom. At a word&mdash;since I must needs, for once, hold a candle to the  devil&mdash;what ransom am I to pay for walking on Watling-street, without  having fifty men at my back?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Were it not well,&rdquo; said the Lieutenant of the gang apart to the  Captain, &ldquo;that the Prior should name the Jew&rsquo;s ransom, and the Jew  name the Prior&rsquo;s?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou art a mad knave,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;but thy plan  transcends!&mdash;Here, Jew, step forth&mdash;Look at that holy Father Aymer,  Prior of the rich Abbey of Jorvaulx, and tell us at what ransom we should hold  him?&mdash;Thou knowest the income of his convent, I warrant thee.&rdquo;          &ldquo;O, assuredly,&rdquo; said Isaac. &ldquo;I have trafficked with the good  fathers, and bought wheat and barley, and fruits of the earth, and also much  wool. O, it is a rich abbey-stede, and they do live upon the fat, and drink the  sweet wines upon the lees, these good fathers of Jorvaulx. Ah, if an outcast  like me had such a home to go to, and such incomings by the year and by the  month, I would pay much gold and silver to redeem my captivity.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Hound of a Jew!&rdquo; exclaimed the Prior, &ldquo;no one knows better  than thy own cursed self, that our holy house of God is indebted for the  finishing of our chancel&mdash;&rdquo;          &ldquo;And for the storing of your cellars in the last season with the due  allowance of Gascon wine,&rdquo; interrupted the Jew; &ldquo;but  that&mdash;that is small matters.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Hear the infidel dog!&rdquo; said the churchman; &ldquo;he jangles as if  our holy community did come under debts for the wines we have a license to  drink, &lsquo;propter necessitatem, et ad frigus depellendum&rsquo;. The  circumcised villain blasphemeth the holy church, and Christian men listen and  rebuke him not!&rdquo;          &ldquo;All this helps nothing,&rdquo; said the leader.&mdash;&ldquo;Isaac,  pronounce what he may pay, without flaying both hide and hair.&rdquo;          &ldquo;An six hundred crowns,&rdquo; said Isaac, &ldquo;the good Prior might  well pay to your honoured valours, and never sit less soft in his stall.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Six hundred crowns,&rdquo; said the leader, gravely; &ldquo;I am  contented&mdash;thou hast well spoken, Isaac&mdash;six hundred crowns.&mdash;It  is a sentence, Sir Prior.&rdquo;          &ldquo;A sentence!&mdash;a sentence!&rdquo; exclaimed the band; &ldquo;Solomon  had not done it better.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou hearest thy doom, Prior,&rdquo; said the leader.          &ldquo;Ye are mad, my masters,&rdquo; said the Prior; &ldquo;where am I to find  such a sum? If I sell the very pyx and candlesticks on the altar at Jorvaulx, I  shall scarce raise the half; and it will be necessary for that purpose that I  go to Jorvaulx myself; ye may retain as borrows   44   my two  priests.&rdquo;          &ldquo;That will be but blind trust,&rdquo; said the Outlaw; &ldquo;we will  retain thee, Prior, and send them to fetch thy ransom. Thou shalt not want a  cup of wine and a collop of venison the while; and if thou lovest woodcraft,  thou shalt see such as your north country never witnessed.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Or, if so please you,&rdquo; said Isaac, willing to curry favour with  the outlaws, &ldquo;I can send to York for the six hundred crowns, out of  certain monies in my hands, if so be that the most reverend Prior present will  grant me a quittance.&rdquo;          &ldquo;He shall grant thee whatever thou dost list, Isaac,&rdquo; said the  Captain; &ldquo;and thou shalt lay down the redemption money for Prior Aymer as  well as for thyself.&rdquo;          &ldquo;For myself! ah, courageous sirs,&rdquo; said the Jew, &ldquo;I am a  broken and impoverished man; a beggar&rsquo;s staff must be my portion through  life, supposing I were to pay you fifty crowns.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The Prior shall judge of that matter,&rdquo; replied the  Captain.&mdash;&ldquo;How say you, Father Aymer? Can the Jew afford a good  ransom?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Can he afford a ransom?&rdquo; answered the Prior &ldquo;Is he not Isaac  of York, rich enough to redeem the captivity of the ten tribes of Israel, who  were led into Assyrian bondage?&mdash;I have seen but little of him myself, but  our cellarer and treasurer have dealt largely with him, and report says that  his house at York is so full of gold and silver as is a shame in any Christian  land. Marvel it is to all living Christian hearts that such gnawing adders  should be suffered to eat into the bowels of the state, and even of the holy  church herself, with foul usuries and extortions.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Hold, father,&rdquo; said the Jew, &ldquo;mitigate and assuage your  choler. I pray of your reverence to remember that I force my monies upon no  one. But when churchman and layman, prince and prior, knight and priest, come  knocking to Isaac&rsquo;s door, they borrow not his shekels with these uncivil  terms. It is then, Friend Isaac, will you pleasure us in this matter, and our  day shall be truly kept, so God sa&rsquo; me?&mdash;and Kind Isaac, if ever you  served man, show yourself a friend in this need! And when the day comes, and I  ask my own, then what hear I but Damned Jew, and The curse of Egypt on your  tribe, and all that may stir up the rude and uncivil populace against poor  strangers!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Prior,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;Jew though he be, he hath in this  spoken well. Do thou, therefore, name his ransom, as he named thine, without  farther rude terms.&rdquo;          &ldquo;None but &lsquo;latro famosus&rsquo;&mdash;the interpretation  whereof,&rdquo; said the Prior, &ldquo;will I give at some other time and  tide&mdash;would place a Christian prelate and an unbaptized Jew upon the same  bench. But since ye require me to put a price upon this caitiff, I tell you  openly that ye will wrong yourselves if you take from him a penny under a  thousand crowns.&rdquo;          &ldquo;A sentence!&mdash;a sentence!&rdquo; exclaimed the chief Outlaw.          &ldquo;A sentence!&mdash;a sentence!&rdquo; shouted his assessors; &ldquo;the  Christian has shown his good nurture, and dealt with us more generously than  the Jew.&rdquo;          &ldquo;The God of my fathers help me!&rdquo; said the Jew; &ldquo;will ye bear  to the ground an impoverished creature?&mdash;I am this day childless, and will  ye deprive me of the means of livelihood?&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou wilt have the less to provide for, Jew, if thou art  childless,&rdquo; said Aymer.          &ldquo;Alas! my lord,&rdquo; said Isaac, &ldquo;your law permits you not to  know how the child of our bosom is entwined with the strings of our  heart&mdash;O Rebecca! laughter of my beloved Rachel! were each leaf on that  tree a zecchin, and each zecchin mine own, all that mass of wealth would I give  to know whether thou art alive, and escaped the hands of the Nazarene!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Was not thy daughter dark-haired?&rdquo; said one of the outlaws;  &ldquo;and wore she not a veil of twisted sendal, broidered with silver?&rdquo;          &ldquo;She did!&mdash;she did!&rdquo; said the old man, trembling with  eagerness, as formerly with fear. &ldquo;The blessing of Jacob be upon thee!  canst thou tell me aught of her safety?&rdquo;          &ldquo;It was she, then,&rdquo; said the yeoman, &ldquo;who was carried off by  the proud Templar, when he broke through our ranks on yester-even. I had drawn  my bow to send a shaft after him, but spared him even for the sake of the  damsel, who I feared might take harm from the arrow.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Oh!&rdquo; answered the Jew, &ldquo;I would to God thou hadst shot,  though the arrow had pierced her bosom!&mdash;Better the tomb of her fathers  than the dishonourable couch of the licentious and savage Templar. Ichabod!  Ichabod! the glory hath departed from my house!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Friends,&rdquo; said the Chief, looking round, &ldquo;the old man is but  a Jew, natheless his grief touches me.&mdash;Deal uprightly with us,  Isaac&mdash;will paying this ransom of a thousand crowns leave thee altogether  penniless?&rdquo;          Isaac, recalled to think of his worldly goods, the love of which, by dint of  inveterate habit, contended even with his parental affection, grew pale,  stammered, and could not deny there might be some small surplus.          &ldquo;Well&mdash;go to&mdash;what though there be,&rdquo; said the Outlaw,  &ldquo;we will not reckon with thee too closely. Without treasure thou mayst as  well hope to redeem thy child from the clutches of Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert,  as to shoot a stag-royal with a headless shaft.&mdash;We will take thee at the  same ransom with Prior Aymer, or rather at one hundred crowns lower, which  hundred crowns shall be mine own peculiar loss, and not light upon this  worshipful community; and so we shall avoid the heinous offence of rating a Jew  merchant as high as a Christian prelate, and thou wilt have six hundred crowns  remaining to treat for thy daughter&rsquo;s ransom. Templars love the glitter  of silver shekels as well as the sparkle of black eyes.&mdash;Hasten to make  thy crowns chink in the ear of De Bois-Guilbert, ere worse comes of it. Thou  wilt find him, as our scouts have brought notice, at the next Preceptory house  of his Order.&mdash;Said I well, my merry mates?&rdquo;          The yeomen expressed their wonted acquiescence in their leader&rsquo;s opinion;  and Isaac, relieved of one half of his apprehensions, by learning that his  daughter lived, and might possibly be ransomed, threw himself at the feet of  the generous Outlaw, and, rubbing his beard against his buskins, sought to kiss  the hem of his green cassock. The Captain drew himself back, and extricated  himself from the Jew&rsquo;s grasp, not without some marks of contempt.          &ldquo;Nay, beshrew thee, man, up with thee! I am English born, and love no  such Eastern prostrations&mdash;Kneel to God, and not to a poor sinner, like  me.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Ay, Jew,&rdquo; said Prior Aymer; &ldquo;kneel to God, as represented in  the servant of his altar, and who knows, with thy sincere repentance and due  gifts to the shrine of Saint Robert, what grace thou mayst acquire for thyself  and thy daughter Rebecca? I grieve for the maiden, for she is of fair and  comely countenance,&mdash;I beheld her in the lists of Ashby. Also Brian de  Bois-Guilbert is one with whom I may do much&mdash;bethink thee how thou mayst  deserve my good word with him.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Alas! alas!&rdquo; said the Jew, &ldquo;on every hand the spoilers arise  against me&mdash;I am given as a prey unto the Assyrian, and a prey unto him of  Egypt.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And what else should be the lot of thy accursed race?&rdquo; answered  the Prior; &ldquo;for what saith holy writ, &lsquo;verbum Domini projecerunt,  et sapientia est nulla in eis&rsquo;&mdash;they have cast forth the word of the  Lord, and there is no wisdom in them; &lsquo;propterea dabo mulieres eorum  exteris&rsquo;&mdash;I will give their women to strangers, that is to the  Templar, as in the present matter; &lsquo;et thesauros eorum haeredibus  alienis&rsquo;, and their treasures to others&mdash;as in the present case to  these honest gentlemen.&rdquo;          Isaac groaned deeply, and began to wring his hands, and to relapse into his  state of desolation and despair. But the leader of the yeomen led him aside.          &ldquo;Advise thee well, Isaac,&rdquo; said Locksley, &ldquo;what thou wilt do  in this matter; my counsel to thee is to make a friend of this churchman. He is  vain, Isaac, and he is covetous; at least he needs money to supply his  profusion. Thou canst easily gratify his greed; for think not that I am blinded  by thy pretexts of poverty. I am intimately acquainted, Isaac, with the very  iron chest in which thou dost keep thy money-bags&mdash;What! know I not the  great stone beneath the apple-tree, that leads into the vaulted chamber under  thy garden at York?&rdquo; The Jew grew as pale as death&mdash;&ldquo;But fear  nothing from me,&rdquo; continued the yeoman, &ldquo;for we are of old  acquainted. Dost thou not remember the sick yeoman whom thy fair daughter  Rebecca redeemed from the gyves at York, and kept him in thy house till his  health was restored, when thou didst dismiss him recovered, and with a piece of  money?&mdash;Usurer as thou art, thou didst never place coin at better interest  than that poor silver mark, for it has this day saved thee five hundred  crowns.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And thou art he whom we called Diccon Bend-the-Bow?&rdquo; said Isaac;  &ldquo;I thought ever I knew the accent of thy voice.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I am Bend-the-Bow,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;and Locksley, and  have a good name besides all these.&rdquo;          &ldquo;But thou art mistaken, good Bend-the-Bow, concerning that same vaulted  apartment. So help me Heaven, as there is nought in it but some merchandises  which I will gladly part with to you&mdash;one hundred yards of Lincoln green  to make doublets to thy men, and a hundred staves of Spanish yew to make bows,  and a hundred silken bowstrings, tough, round, and sound&mdash;these will I  send thee for thy good-will, honest Diccon, an thou wilt keep silence about the  vault, my good Diccon.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Silent as a dormouse,&rdquo; said the Outlaw; &ldquo;and never trust me  but I am grieved for thy daughter. But I may not help it&mdash;The Templars  lances are too strong for my archery in the open field&mdash;they would scatter  us like dust. Had I but known it was Rebecca when she was borne off, something  might have been done; but now thou must needs proceed by policy. Come, shall I  treat for thee with the Prior?&rdquo;          &ldquo;In God&rsquo;s name, Diccon, an thou canst, aid me to recover the child  of my bosom!&rdquo;          &ldquo;Do not thou interrupt me with thine ill-timed avarice,&rdquo; said the  Outlaw, &ldquo;and I will deal with him in thy behalf.&rdquo;          He then turned from the Jew, who followed him, however, as closely as his  shadow.          &ldquo;Prior Aymer,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;come apart with me under  this tree. Men say thou dost love wine, and a lady&rsquo;s smile, better than  beseems thy Order, Sir Priest; but with that I have nought to do. I have heard,  too, thou dost love a brace of good dogs and a fleet horse, and it may well be  that, loving things which are costly to come by, thou hatest not a purse of  gold. But I have never heard that thou didst love oppression or  cruelty.&mdash;Now, here is Isaac willing to give thee the means of pleasure  and pastime in a bag containing one hundred marks of silver, if thy  intercession with thine ally the Templar shall avail to procure the freedom of  his daughter.&rdquo;          &ldquo;In safety and honour, as when taken from me,&rdquo; said the Jew,  &ldquo;otherwise it is no bargain.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Peace, Isaac,&rdquo; said the Outlaw, &ldquo;or I give up thine  interest.&mdash;What say you to this my purpose, Prior Aymer?&rdquo;          &ldquo;The matter,&rdquo; quoth the Prior, &ldquo;is of a mixed condition; for,  if I do a good deal on the one hand, yet, on the other, it goeth to the vantage  of a Jew, and in so much is against my conscience. Yet, if the Israelite will  advantage the Church by giving me somewhat over to the building of our dortour,    45   I will take it on my conscience to  aid him in the matter of his daughter.&rdquo;          &ldquo;For a score of marks to the dortour,&rdquo; said the  Outlaw,&mdash;&ldquo;Be still, I say, Isaac!&mdash;or for a brace of silver  candlesticks to the altar, we will not stand with you.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay, but, good Diccon Bend-the-Bow&rdquo;&mdash;said Isaac, endeavouring  to interpose.          &ldquo;Good Jew&mdash;good beast&mdash;good earthworm!&rdquo; said the yeoman,  losing patience; &ldquo;an thou dost go on to put thy filthy lucre in the  balance with thy daughter&rsquo;s life and honour, by Heaven, I will strip thee  of every maravedi thou hast in the world, before three days are out!&rdquo;          Isaac shrunk together, and was silent.          &ldquo;And what pledge am I to have for all this?&rdquo; said the Prior.          &ldquo;When Isaac returns successful through your mediation,&rdquo; said the  Outlaw, &ldquo;I swear by Saint Hubert, I will see that he pays thee the money  in good silver, or I will reckon with him for it in such sort, he had better  have paid twenty such sums.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Well then, Jew,&rdquo; said Aymer, &ldquo;since I must needs meddle in  this matter, let me have the use of thy writing-tablets&mdash;though,  hold&mdash;rather than use thy pen, I would fast for twenty-four hours, and  where shall I find one?&rdquo;          &ldquo;If your holy scruples can dispense with using the Jew&rsquo;s tablets,  for the pen I can find a remedy,&rdquo; said the yeoman; and, bending his bow,  he aimed his shaft at a wild-goose which was soaring over their heads, the  advanced-guard of a phalanx of his tribe, which were winging their way to the  distant and solitary fens of Holderness. The bird came fluttering down,  transfixed with the arrow.          &ldquo;There, Prior,&rdquo; said the Captain, &ldquo;are quills enow to supply  all the monks of Jorvaulx for the next hundred years, an they take not to  writing chronicles.&rdquo;          The Prior sat down, and at great leisure indited an epistle to Brian de  Bois-Guilbert, and having carefully sealed up the tablets, delivered them to  the Jew, saying, &ldquo;This will be thy safe-conduct to the Preceptory of  Templestowe, and, as I think, is most likely to accomplish the delivery of thy  daughter, if it be well backed with proffers of advantage and commodity at  thine own hand; for, trust me well, the good Knight Bois-Guilbert is of their  confraternity that do nought for nought.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Well, Prior,&rdquo; said the Outlaw, &ldquo;I will detain thee no longer  here than to give the Jew a quittance for the six hundred crowns at which thy  ransom is fixed&mdash;I accept of him for my pay-master; and if I hear that ye  boggle at allowing him in his accompts the sum so paid by him, Saint Mary  refuse me, an I burn not the abbey over thine head, though I hang ten years the  sooner!&rdquo;          With a much worse grace than that wherewith he had penned the letter to  Bois-Guilbert, the Prior wrote an acquittance, discharging Isaac of York of six  hundred crowns, advanced to him in his need for acquittal of his ransom, and  faithfully promising to hold true compt with him for that sum.          &ldquo;And now,&rdquo; said Prior Aymer, &ldquo;I will pray you of restitution  of my mules and palfreys, and the freedom of the reverend brethren attending  upon me, and also of the gymmal rings, jewels, and fair vestures, of which I  have been despoiled, having now satisfied you for my ransom as a true  prisoner.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Touching your brethren, Sir Prior,&rdquo; said Locksley, &ldquo;they  shall have present freedom, it were unjust to detain them; touching your horses  and mules, they shall also be restored, with such spending-money as may enable  you to reach York, for it were cruel to deprive you of the means of  journeying.&mdash;But as concerning rings, jewels, chains, and what else, you  must understand that we are men of tender consciences, and will not yield to a  venerable man like yourself, who should be dead to the vanities of this life,  the strong temptation to break the rule of his foundation, by wearing rings,  chains, or other vain gauds.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Think what you do, my masters,&rdquo; said the Prior, &ldquo;ere you put  your hand on the Church&rsquo;s patrimony&mdash;These things are &lsquo;inter  res sacras&rsquo;, and I wot not what judgment might ensue were they to be  handled by laical hands.&rdquo;          &ldquo;I will take care of that, reverend Prior,&rdquo; said the Hermit of  Copmanhurst; &ldquo;for I will wear them myself.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Friend, or brother,&rdquo; said the Prior, in answer to this solution of  his doubts, &ldquo;if thou hast really taken religious orders, I pray thee to  look how thou wilt answer to thine official for the share thou hast taken in  this day&rsquo;s work.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Friend Prior,&rdquo; returned the Hermit, &ldquo;you are to know that I  belong to a little diocese, where I am my own diocesan, and care as little for  the Bishop of York as I do for the Abbot of Jorvaulx, the Prior, and all the  convent.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou art utterly irregular,&rdquo; said the Prior; &ldquo;one of those  disorderly men, who, taking on them the sacred character without due cause,  profane the holy rites, and endanger the souls of those who take counsel at  their hands; &lsquo;lapides pro pane condonantes iis&rsquo;, giving them stones  instead of bread as the Vulgate hath it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Nay,&rdquo; said the Friar, &ldquo;an my brain-pan could have been  broken by Latin, it had not held so long together.&mdash;I say, that easing a  world of such misproud priests as thou art of their jewels and their gimcracks,  is a lawful spoiling of the Egyptians.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou be&rsquo;st a hedge-priest,&rdquo;   46   said the Prior,  in great wrath, &ldquo;&lsquo;excommunicabo vos&rsquo;.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Thou be&rsquo;st thyself more like a thief and a heretic,&rdquo; said  the Friar, equally indignant; &ldquo;I will pouch up no such affront before my  parishioners, as thou thinkest it not shame to put upon me, although I be a  reverend brother to thee. &lsquo;Ossa ejus perfringam&rsquo;, I will break your  bones, as the Vulgate hath it.&rdquo;          &ldquo;Hola!&rdquo; cried the Captain, &ldquo;come the reverend brethren to  such terms?&mdash;Keep thine assurance of peace, Friar.&mdash;Prior, an thou  hast not made thy peace perfect with God, provoke the Friar no  further.&mdash;Hermit, let the reverend father depart in peace, as a ransomed  man.&rdquo;          The yeomen separated the incensed priests, who continued to raise their voices,  vituperating each other in bad Latin, which the Prior delivered the more  fluently, and the Hermit with the greater vehemence. The Prior at length  recollected himself sufficiently to be aware that he was compromising his  dignity, by squabbling with such a hedge-priest as the Outlaw&rsquo;s chaplain,  and being joined by his attendants, rode off with considerably less pomp, and  in a much more apostolical condition, so far as worldly matters were concerned,  than he had exhibited before this rencounter.          It remained that the Jew should produce some security for the ransom which he  was to pay on the Prior&rsquo;s account, as well as upon his own. He gave,  accordingly, an order sealed with his signet, to a brother of his tribe at  York, requiring him to pay to the bearer the sum of a thousand crowns, and to  deliver certain merchandises specified in the note.          &ldquo;My brother Sheva,&rdquo; he said, groaning deeply, &ldquo;hath the key  of my warehouses.&rdquo;          &ldquo;And of the vaulted chamber,&rdquo; whispered Locksley.          &ldquo;No, no&mdash;may Heaven forefend!&rdquo; said Isaac; &ldquo;evil is the  hour that let any one whomsoever into that secret!&rdquo;          &ldquo;It is safe with me,&rdquo; said the Outlaw, &ldquo;so be that this thy  scroll produce the sum therein nominated and set down.&mdash;But what now,  Isaac? art dead? art stupefied? hath the payment of a thousand crowns put thy  daughter&rsquo;s peril out of thy mind?&rdquo;          The Jew started to his feet&mdash;&ldquo;No, Diccon, no&mdash;I will presently  set forth.&mdash;Farewell, thou whom I may not call good, and dare not and will  not call evil.&rdquo;          Yet ere Isaac departed, the Outlaw Chief bestowed on him this parting  advice:&mdash;&ldquo;Be liberal of thine offers, Isaac, and spare not thy purse  for thy daughter&rsquo;s safety. Credit me, that the gold thou shalt spare in  her cause, will hereafter give thee as much agony as if it were poured molten  down thy throat.&rdquo;          Isaac acquiesced with a deep groan, and set forth on his journey, accompanied  by two tall foresters, who were to be his guides, and at the same time his  guards, through the wood.
